title: For Hire Vehicles (FHV) - Active
ufd: This dataset contains information on active for-hire vehicles licensed by the TLC. It is updated daily and includes details such as vehicle license number, driver name, license type, and expiration date. Key columns include `vehicle_license_number`, `name` of the driver, `license_type` which is consistently "FOR HIRE VEHICLE", and `expiration_date` of the license. The dataset also provides information about the base or company the vehicle is associated with, including `base_number`, `base_name`, `base_type` (e.g., BLACK-CAR, LIVERY), `base_telephone_number`, and `base_address`. Researchers and transportation planners can use this dataset to analyze trends in the for-hire vehicle industry, track vehicle and driver licensing, and understand the distribution of different base types across the city. The `active` column indicates whether a vehicle is currently in good standing and authorized to operate. The `vehicle_year` column can be used to assess the age and potential environmental impact of the for-hire vehicle fleet.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides daily updates on active for-hire vehicles licensed by the TLC, including vehicle and driver details, license information, and base affiliations. It contains information such as vehicle license number, driver name, license type, expiration date, and base details like name, type, and contact information. The dataset is useful for analyzing trends in the for-hire vehicle industry and tracking licensing information.

Related Topics:
- For-Hire Vehicles
- Transportation Network Companies (TNCs)
- Vehicle Licensing
- Driver Licensing
- Transportation Planning
- Urban Mobility
- Taxi and Limousine Commission (TLC)
- Base Stations

Concepts and Synonyms:
- For-Hire Vehicle: FHV, Taxi, Livery Vehicle, Black Car
- Base: Dispatch Center, Company, Affiliated Organization
- License: Permit, Authorization, Credential
- Active: In Good Standing, Valid, Authorized to Operate
- TLC: Taxi and Limousine Commission, Regulatory Agency
- Vehicle: Automobile, Car, Motor Vehicle

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the growth and distribution of for-hire vehicles.
- Track vehicle and driver licensing trends over time.
- Identify the distribution of different base types (e.g., black car, livery) across the city.
- Assess the age and potential environmental impact of the for-hire vehicle fleet using the `vehicle_year` column.
- Investigate the relationship between base characteristics and vehicle activity.
- Monitor compliance with licensing regulations.
- Develop transportation planning strategies based on for-hire vehicle data.

title: Civil Service List (Active)
ufd: This dataset contains information about active civil service lists, which are rankings of candidates who passed an exam for city government positions. Each row represents a candidate on a list and includes their exam number, name, and adjusted final average score ("adj_fa"). The dataset also provides details about the specific job title ("list_title_desc"), the agency associated with the list ("list_agency_desc"), and important dates such as when the list was established and its anniversary date. Researchers or job seekers might use this data to analyze trends in civil service hiring, explore the types of positions available, or track the lifecycle of different civil service lists. Note that some columns, such as "published_date" and "extension_date," have a high percentage of missing values. The "exam_no" column serves as a unique identifier for each exam.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides details on active civil service lists within a city government, including candidate rankings, exam scores, and list-specific information. It contains data on individuals who have passed civil service exams and are eligible for various government positions. The dataset includes details such as exam number, candidate name, adjusted final average score, job title, agency, and key dates related to the list's lifecycle.

Related Topics:
- Civil Service
- Government Jobs
- Public Sector Employment
- Hiring Processes
- Exam Results
- Candidate Rankings

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Civil Service List: Eligible candidate list, hiring roster, employment register
- Exam Number: Test ID, Examination identifier
- Adjusted Final Average Score: Adj_FA, Final score, Exam performance
- List Title Description: Job title, Position name, Role description
- List Agency Description: Department, Government agency, Hiring organization

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze trends in civil service hiring across different agencies and job titles.
- Explore the distribution of exam scores and identify high-performing candidates.
- Track the lifecycle of civil service lists, including establishment and expiration dates.
- Investigate the relationship between exam scores and job placement outcomes (if linked to other datasets).
- Identify potential areas for improvement in the civil service examination process.

title: Citywide Payroll Data (Fiscal Year)
ufd: This dataset provides a snapshot of citywide payroll information for the fiscal year 2025, focusing on employees within the "ADMIN FOR CHILDREN'S SVCS" agency. Each row represents an individual employee and includes details such as their name, agency start date, and work location borough. The dataset also contains information about the employee's job title, leave status, and compensation. Key columns include `base_salary`, `regular_gross_paid`, `total_ot_paid`, and `total_other_pay`, offering a comprehensive view of employee earnings. Researchers and analysts can use this data to understand payroll distribution within the agency, analyze overtime spending, and examine compensation trends across different job titles and boroughs. Please note that this sample only contains data from a single agency and fiscal year. The dataset includes the regular hours worked by each employee, as well as overtime hours.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains payroll information for employees within the "ADMIN FOR CHILDREN'S SVCS" agency for fiscal year 2025. It includes details such as employee name, start date, borough, job title, leave status, and various compensation components like base salary, regular gross pay, overtime pay, and other pay. The data also includes regular and overtime hours worked.

title: Motor Vehicle Collisions - Crashes
ufd: This dataset contains information about motor vehicle collisions in New York City, with each row representing a single crash event. Key details include the crash date and time, the streets where the collision occurred (on_street_name, off_street_name), and the number of people injured or killed. The dataset also provides insights into the factors contributing to the crash, such as driver inattention or speeding, and the types of vehicles involved. Researchers and public safety officials can use this data to identify high-risk areas, understand the causes of collisions, and develop strategies to improve traffic safety. The data includes the number of injuries and fatalities for different types of people involved, such as pedestrians, cyclists, and motorists. This information can be used to analyze trends and patterns in collisions, and to evaluate the effectiveness of safety interventions.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details motor vehicle collisions in New York City, with each entry representing a single crash. It includes the date, time, and location of the crash, along with the number of injuries and fatalities. Contributing factors like driver inattention and vehicle types are also recorded, providing a comprehensive view of collision events.

Related Topics:
- Traffic Safety

- Accident Analysis
- Transportation Engineering

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Motor Vehicle Collision: Car accident, traffic crash, vehicle collision, road accident
- Injuries: Wounded, harmed, casualties, injured persons
- Fatalities: Deaths, killed, mortalities, deceased
- Contributing Factors: Causes, reasons, contributing circumstances, accident factors
- Vehicle Types: Car, truck, motorcycle, bus, taxi, bicycle, pedestrian

Applications and Use Cases:
- Identify high-risk areas for collisions.
- Analyze the causes of motor vehicle accidents.
- Develop strategies to improve traffic safety.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of safety interventions.
- Analyze trends and patterns in collisions involving pedestrians and cyclists.
- Predict future collision hotspots based on historical data.

title: For Hire Vehicles (FHV) - Active Drivers
ufd: This dataset contains information on active, licensed For Hire Vehicle (FHV) drivers in New York City. Each row represents a driver and includes their license number, name, and the expiration date of their license. The "wheelchair_accessible_trained" column indicates whether the driver is trained to operate wheelchair-accessible vehicles. The dataset is updated daily, and the "last_date_updated" and "last_time_updated" columns reflect the last time the data was refreshed. This information can be used to verify the status and credentials of FHV drivers. You can also use this dataset to analyze trends in FHV driver licensing and wheelchair accessibility within the FHV sector.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides details on active, licensed For Hire Vehicle (FHV) drivers in New York City. It includes driver license information, name, license expiration date, and wheelchair accessibility training status. The dataset is updated daily, offering a current snapshot of FHV driver credentials and training.

title: Civil Service List Certification
ufd: This dataset contains information on Civil Service List Certifications, which are lists of eligible candidates for city government positions. Each row represents a candidate on a certification list. Key details include the candidate's name, the agency and job title they are being considered for, and the date the certification was requested and issued. The dataset also includes salary information and the number of vacancies for the position. Researchers and job seekers can use this data to understand the hiring process for city government jobs, identify in-demand skills and agencies, and track the timelines associated with civil service certifications. The `exam_no` and `list_agency_code` columns provide unique identifiers for exams and agencies, while `list_title_desc` specifies the job title. The `request_date`, `cert_date`, and `cert_expiration_date` columns offer a timeline of the certification process.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides comprehensive information on Civil Service List Certifications within a city government, detailing eligible candidates for various positions. Each record represents a candidate's listing, including their name, the agency and job title, and key dates related to the certification process. Salary information and vacancy counts are also included, offering insights into the hiring landscape.

title: DOHMH New York City Restaurant Inspection Results
ufd: This dataset contains restaurant inspection results for New York City, offering insights into the health and safety standards of local eateries. Each row represents a specific inspection record, identified by a unique CAMIS number. Key details include the restaurant's name (DBA), location (Boro, Building, Street, Zipcode, Latitude, Longitude), and inspection date. The dataset highlights critical violations (Critical_flag), cuisine type, and any actions taken as a result of the inspection. Researchers, health officials, and the public can use this data to assess restaurant compliance, identify trends in food safety, and make informed decisions about dining options. Note that an inspection date of 1900-01-01 indicates that the restaurant is new and has not yet been inspected. The record date indicates when the data was pulled.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed restaurant inspection results for New York City, encompassing key information about food safety and hygiene standards. Each record represents a single inspection, including restaurant details, violation specifics, and inspection outcomes. The data allows for analysis of restaurant compliance and identification of food safety trends.

- DBA: Doing Business As, restaurant name, business name

title: Film Permits
ufd: This dataset contains information about permits required for exclusive use of city property in New York City, with a focus on film and media productions. Each row represents a permit, identified by a unique `eventid`, and includes details such as the `eventtype` (e.g., Shooting Permit, Theater Load in), `startdatetime` and `enddatetime` of the permitted activity. The `eventagency` is the Mayor's Office of Media & Entertainment. Location information is provided through `parkingheld` (street address), `borough`, `communityboard_s`, `policeprecinct_s`, and `zipcode_s`. The dataset also categorizes the type of production (`category` and `subcategoryname`), such as Television (Cable-episodic) or Film (Feature). You can use this dataset to analyze trends in film and media production across different boroughs, identify frequently requested locations, or understand the duration of permitted activities.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details permits issued by New York City for exclusive use of city property, primarily focusing on film and media productions. Each record represents a unique permit, identified by an event ID, and includes information about the event type, date and time, location, and the type of production. The data is managed by the Mayor's Office of Media & Entertainment.

- Production Type: Category, Subcategory, Film, Television, Commercial

title: DOB Permit Issuance
ufd: This dataset contains information about permits issued by the New York City Department of Buildings (DOB) for construction and demolition activities. Each row represents a single permit for a specific type of work, updated daily to reflect the latest application status. Key columns include `borough`, `bin__` (Building Identification Number), `house__` and `street_name` to identify the location of the permitted work. The `job__` column provides a unique identifier for the overall construction job, while `job_type` specifies the type of application (e.g., New Building, Demolition). Dates such as `filing_date`, `issuance_date`, and `expiration_date` track the permit's lifecycle. Researchers, developers, and city planners can use this dataset to analyze construction trends, track permit approvals, and understand development patterns across New York City. The data also includes details about the permittee and property owner, offering insights into the stakeholders involved in construction projects.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

It includes information on permit type, location (borough, BIN, address), key dates (filing, issuance, expiration), and involved parties. title: Open Parking and Camera Violations
ufd: This dataset contains information on parking and camera violations issued in New York City. Each row represents a single violation, with details such as the license plate, state, and type of license involved. The dataset includes the date and time the violation was issued, as well as the specific violation type (e.g., "NO PARKING-STREET CLEANING" or "PHTO SCHOOL ZN SPEED VIOLATION"). Financial information, including fine amount, penalty amount, interest, and payments, is provided, along with the amount still due. You can also find the precinct and county where the violation occurred, and the issuing agency. A link to an image of the summons is included for each violation. This data could be used to analyze parking violation patterns, assess revenue generated from fines, or examine the effectiveness of different traffic regulations.
sfd:

title: Medallion Drivers - Active
ufd: This dataset contains a list of active, licensed medallion taxi drivers in New York City. Each row represents a single driver and includes their license number, name, and the type of license they hold, which is consistently "MEDALLION TAXI DRIVER". The dataset also provides the expiration date of the driver's license. The `last_updated_date` and `last_updated_time` columns indicate when the dataset was last refreshed, ensuring the information is current. This dataset could be used to verify the credentials of taxi drivers or to analyze trends in the taxi industry. Note that the dataset is updated daily, so checking the 'Last Update Date' is important. The dataset includes 100 unique drivers.
sfd:

title: NYPD Complaint Data Historic
ufd: This dataset contains detailed information on complaints reported to the New York City Police Department (NYPD). Each row represents a single complaint, including the date and time the complaint was made (`cmplnt_fr_dt`, `cmplnt_fr_tm`, `cmplnt_to_dt`, `cmplnt_to_tm`), the type of offense (`ofns_desc`), and the location where it occurred (`boro_nm`, `addr_pct_cd`). The dataset also includes information about the victim (`vic_age_group`, `vic_race`, `vic_sex`) and any suspects (`susp_age_group`, `susp_race`, `susp_sex`). Researchers and public safety analysts can use this data to analyze crime patterns, identify trends in specific offenses, and understand the demographics of victims and suspects. The `law_cat_cd` column indicates whether the offense was a felony, misdemeanor, or violation. The precinct code (`addr_pct_cd`) can be used to map crime incidents to specific areas of the city.
sfd:

title: 2015 Street Tree Census - Tree Data
ufd: This dataset contains information collected during the 2015 Street Tree Census in New York City. It provides a snapshot of the city's street trees, including their species (spc_common, spc_latin), health (health), and diameter (tree_dbh). The data also includes location information such as address, zipcode, borough (boroname), latitude, and longitude. Key columns like 'status' indicate whether a tree is alive, dead, or a stump, while 'problems' lists any issues observed, such as stones or wires. Researchers, urban planners, and environmental advocates can use this dataset to analyze tree distribution, assess tree health, and identify areas needing improved tree care. The 'created_at' column indicates when the tree data was recorded. This information can be valuable for understanding the urban forest and its impact on the city's environment.
sfd:

title: DOB NOW: Build – Approved Permits
ufd: This dataset contains information on approved construction permits in New York City, excluding electrical, elevator, and limited alteration applications, which have their own datasets. Each row represents a permit and includes details such as the job filing number, work permit number, and the reason for filing (initial or renewal). Location information is provided through the house number, street name, borough, lot, BIN (Building Identification Number), block, and NTA (Neighborhood Tabulation Area). The dataset also specifies the type of work being done (e.g., structural, plumbing) and the floor(s) where the work is taking place. Key personnel involved are identified by their license type and numbers, as well as their names and business information. Dates for approval, issuance, and expiration of the permits are included, along with the permit status (issued or signed-off). Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze construction trends, track permit approvals, and understand the types of construction activities occurring in different neighborhoods.
sfd:

title: Housing Maintenance Code Violations
ufd: This dataset contains records of housing maintenance code violations issued by the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD). Each row represents a single violation, identified by a unique `violationid`. The data includes details about the building where the violation occurred, such as `buildingid`, `boro`, `housenumber`, `streetname`, and `zip`. The `novdescription` column provides a description of the violation, while `inspectiondate` and `novissueddate` indicate when the inspection took place and the violation was issued. The current status of the violation (`currentstatus`) and its classification (`class`) are also included. Researchers, landlords, tenants, and city planners can use this dataset to analyze housing quality, identify areas with high violation rates, and track the resolution of housing maintenance issues. The `rentimpairing` column indicates if the violation affects the rent, which is useful for tenant advocacy and legal aid organizations.
sfd:

title: DOB Job Application Filings
ufd: This dataset contains job application filings submitted to the New York City Department of Buildings (DOB). It provides details on building projects, including location information such as borough, house number, street name, block, and lot. Key columns include job type, job status, and descriptions of the work being done. The latest action date indicates when the most recent activity occurred on the application. Researchers, urban planners, and real estate professionals can use this dataset to analyze construction trends, track project progress, and gain insights into development activities across the city. The dataset also includes information about the applicant and property owner, as well as costs and fees associated with the job. Note that this dataset does not include jobs submitted through DOB NOW; see the linked dataset for those filings.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains job application filings submitted to the New York City Department of Buildings (DOB), excluding those submitted through DOB NOW. It includes detailed information on building projects across NYC, such as location, job type, status, work descriptions, and application dates. The data also covers applicant and property owner details, along with associated costs and fees.

Related Topics:
  - Construction
  - Urban Planning
  - Real Estate
  - New York City
  - Building Permits
  - Development
  - Housing

Concepts and Synonyms:
  - Job Application Filing: Building permit application, construction permit, project filing
  - DOB: Department of Buildings, NYC DOB
  - Job Type: Construction type, project category, building work type
  - Job Status: Application status, permit status, project stage
  - Location Information: Borough, block, lot, address, property location
  - Latest Action Date: Last updated, recent activity date, most recent filing date

Applications and Use Cases:
  - Analyze construction trends in NYC by borough and neighborhood.
  - Track the progress of building projects based on job status and latest action date.
  - Identify areas with high levels of development activity.
  - Research the types of construction projects being undertaken.
  - Investigate costs and fees associated with different types of building jobs.
  - Study application patterns and processing times.

title: NYPD Shooting Incident Data (Year To Date)
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed look at shooting incidents in New York City during the current calendar year. Each row represents a single shooting incident, offering insights into the location, time, and individuals involved. Key columns include `occur_date` and `occur_time` for when the incident happened, `boro` and `precinct` for location details, and `perp_age_group`, `perp_sex`, `perp_race`, `vic_age_group`, `vic_sex`, and `vic_race` for demographic information about perpetrators and victims. The `statistical_murder_flag` indicates whether the incident is classified as a murder. Researchers, policymakers, and the public can use this data to analyze trends in shooting incidents, understand the demographics of those affected, and inform strategies for improving public safety. The location descriptions provide further detail, classifying incidents by `loc_classfctn_desc` such as street or housing, and `location_desc` providing more specific details. The dataset also includes geographic coordinates (`latitude`, `longitude`) for mapping and spatial analysis.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains detailed information on shooting incidents in New York City for the current year. It includes specifics on the time and location of each incident, as well as demographic details of both perpetrators and victims. The data allows for analysis of shooting trends, affected populations, and spatial patterns related to gun violence in NYC.

- Crime Statistics
- Gun Violence
- Public Health
- Demographics
- New York City
- Law Enforcement
- Incident Reporting

- Shooting Incident: Gun violence, firearm assault, shooting event

- Victim: Injured party, casualty, target

- Demographics: Age, sex, race, population characteristics

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze trends in shooting incidents over time and by location.
- Identify demographic patterns of victims and perpetrators.
- Map shooting incidents to identify high-risk areas.
- Inform public safety strategies and resource allocation.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of crime prevention programs.
- Research the relationship between socioeconomic factors and gun violence.

title: DOB NOW: Build – Job Application Filings
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed look into job application filings in New York City through the DOB NOW: Build system. It includes records of various construction and alteration projects, offering insights into the city's development landscape. Each entry contains a unique job filing number, the current filing status (e.g., "Approved," "Permit Entire," or "LOC Issued"), and the location of the project, including house number, street name, and borough. You can also find information on the type of work being done, such as plumbing or sprinkler work, the initial cost of the project, and whether the project complies with NYC energy conservation codes. The dataset further details the involved parties, such as the applicant's professional title and license number, and the filing representative's information. Researchers, urban planners, and real estate professionals can use this data to analyze construction trends, track project approvals, and assess compliance with building codes across different boroughs. The community board and lot number are also included, offering more granular location data.
sfd:

title: DSNY Monthly Tonnage Data
ufd: This dataset provides monthly data on the tons of waste collected by the New York City Department of Sanitation (DSNY) from residences and institutions. The data is broken down by borough and community district, offering a geographical perspective on waste management. Key columns include the month of collection, the borough, the community district, and the tons collected for different waste types: refuse, paper, metal/glass/plastic (MGP), residential organics, school organics, and other organics. The `borough_id` column provides a numerical identifier for each borough. This dataset can be used to analyze waste collection patterns across different areas of New York City, track trends in waste generation and recycling, and evaluate the effectiveness of waste management programs. Researchers, city planners, and environmental advocates can leverage this information to inform policy decisions, optimize resource allocation, and promote sustainable waste management practices.

title: NYPD Arrest Data (Year to Date)
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed look at arrests made by the NYPD in New York City. Each row represents a single arrest and includes information such as the date of the arrest (`arrest_date`), the type of offense (`ofns_desc` and `pd_desc`), and the relevant legal codes (`law_code` and `law_cat_cd`). The dataset also contains demographic information about the person arrested, including their age group (`age_group`), sex (`perp_sex`), and race (`perp_race`). Location information is provided through borough (`arrest_boro`) and precinct (`arrest_precinct`). Researchers, policymakers, and the public can use this data to analyze crime patterns, understand law enforcement activities, and explore demographic trends related to arrests in NYC. The `arrest_key` column serves as a unique identifier for each arrest record. Additional geographic regions are also included, though their specific definitions are not provided.
sfd:

title: NYPD Complaint Data Current (Year To Date)
ufd: This dataset contains information about complaints reported to the New York City Police Department (NYPD). Each row represents a single complaint and includes details about the incident. Key columns include `cmplnt_num` for the complaint number, `cmplnt_fr_dt` and `cmplnt_fr_tm` for the date and time the complaint was made, and `ofns_desc` for the offense description. The dataset also provides location information such as `boro_nm` for the borough and `addr_pct_cd` for the police precinct. Information about the suspect and victim, such as age group, race, and sex, are also included. Researchers and analysts can use this dataset to study crime patterns, identify high-crime areas, and analyze demographic trends related to crime in New York City. The data can also be used to improve public safety strategies and resource allocation.

title: Air Quality
ufd: This dataset provides air quality surveillance data for New York City, focusing on the summer of 2023. It includes measurements of pollutants like Nitrogen dioxide (NO2), Fine particles (PM 2.5), and Ozone (O3). The `data_value` column represents the mean concentration of these pollutants, measured in parts per billion (ppb) or micrograms per cubic meter (mcg/m3), as indicated by the `measure_info` column. Data is categorized by geographic areas, specified by `geo_type_name` (e.g., CD for Community District, UHF for United Hospital Fund district) and `geo_place_name`, allowing users to analyze air quality variations across different neighborhoods. The `geo_join_id` can be used to link this data with other datasets containing geographic information. Researchers and policymakers can use this dataset to assess air quality levels, identify pollution hotspots, and track changes over time to inform public health interventions. The dataset's temporal focus is on the "Summer 2023" time period, with a `start_date` of June 1, 2023.
sfd:

title: Daily Inmates In Custody
ufd: This dataset provides information on daily inmates in custody, offering insights into the characteristics of the incarcerated population. Key details include the inmate's custody level (MAX, MED, MIN), mental health designation (BRADH), race, gender, and age. The dataset also tracks the inmate's legal status via an inmate status code, security risk group membership (SRG_FLG), top charge, and whether they have had any infractions. Notably, sealed cases are excluded from this dataset. Researchers and public safety analysts can use this data to analyze trends in incarceration, assess the demographics of inmates, and understand factors related to custody level and infractions. The `admitted_dt` column indicates when an inmate was admitted.

title: Jobs NYC Postings
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive overview of job opportunities within New York City government agencies. It includes both internal and external job postings, offering insights into a wide range of positions. Key columns include 'agency' indicating the hiring department, 'business_title' and 'civil_service_title' specifying the job title, 'job_category' grouping positions by function, and 'salary_range_from' and 'salary_range_to' outlining the compensation scale. The dataset also details the 'posting_type' (internal or external), 'number_of_positions' available, 'full_time_part_time_indicator', and 'career_level'. Users can leverage this data to explore career paths within NYC government, analyze salary trends across different agencies and job categories, or identify required qualifications and preferred skills for specific roles. The 'job_description' column provides detailed information about responsibilities, while 'minimum_qual_requirements' outlines the necessary qualifications.

title: 2020 Neighborhood Tabulation Areas (NTAs)
ufd: This dataset provides geographic boundaries and attributes for the 2020 Neighborhood Tabulation Areas (NTAs) in New York City. NTAs are statistical geographies used for reporting data from the Decennial Census and American Community Survey. Key columns include `boroname` and `ntaname`, specifying the borough and neighborhood name, respectively, and `countyfips`, a unique identifier. The `the_geom` column contains the geospatial data defining the boundaries of each NTA. Researchers, city planners, and analysts can use this dataset to visualize neighborhood-level data, perform spatial analysis, and understand demographic patterns across New York City. The dataset also includes Community District Tabulation Areas (CDTA) information, allowing for comparisons between NTAs and larger community districts.

title: DOB Complaints Received
ufd: This dataset contains records of complaints received by the New York City Department of Buildings (DOB), including those submitted through 311 or entered directly by DOB staff. Each row represents a single complaint, identified by a unique complaint number. The data includes the status of the complaint (e.g., "CLOSED" or "ACTIVE"), the date it was entered, and the address of the property in question, including house number, street, zip code, and community board. The dataset also categorizes the complaint type and provides a unit identifier, as well as disposition and inspection dates and codes. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze trends in building-related complaints, identify areas with high complaint volumes, and assess the effectiveness of DOB's complaint resolution process. The `complaint_category` column provides insights into the types of issues being reported, while the `status` and disposition-related columns offer information on how complaints are handled. The `zip_code` and `community_board` columns can be used to spatially analyze complaint patterns across the city.

title: NYC Civil Service Titles
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive list of civil service job titles within New York City government. It includes details such as the title code, job description, standard working hours, and assignment level. A key feature of the dataset is its detailed information on union affiliation, including the union code, a description of the union, the bargaining unit, and a more detailed description of the bargaining unit. Salary ranges are also provided, with both minimum and maximum rates for each position. Finally, the dataset indicates whether an investigation is required before an appointment for each title. Researchers and job seekers can use this dataset to understand the landscape of city government jobs, explore salary expectations, and learn about union representation.

title: Automated Traffic Volume Counts
ufd: This dataset contains traffic volume counts collected by the New York City Department of Transportation (NYC DOT) using Automated Traffic Recorders (ATR) on roadways and bridge crossings. The data includes the borough (`boro`) where the recording took place, the year (`yr`), month (`m`), day (`d`), hour (`hh`), and minute (`mm`) of the recording. The `vol` column represents the traffic volume count at a specific location identified by `segmentid` and described by the street name (`street`), the starting street (`fromst`), and the ending street (`tost`). The location is further specified using WKT geometry (`wktgeom`). This data can be used to analyze traffic patterns, identify congestion points, and understand traffic flow in different areas of New York City. The direction of traffic is indicated in the `direction` column.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

The data covers roadways and bridge crossings in New York City and can be used for traffic analysis and congestion studies.

title: Evictions
ufd: This dataset provides a record of executed evictions in New York City's five boroughs from 2017 to the present. Compiled from New York City Marshals, the data includes details such as the court index number, docket number, and eviction address. You can identify whether the eviction was for a residential or commercial property and the borough and zip code where it occurred. The dataset also contains the names of the Marshals who carried out the eviction. Location data, including latitude, longitude, community board, council district, and census tract, are available for most evictions. This information can be used to analyze eviction patterns across the city, understand the demographics of affected areas, and assess the impact of housing policies.

title: Issued Licenses
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive view of licenses issued by the NYC Department of Consumer and Worker Protection (DCWP), offering insights into the diverse range of businesses operating in New York City. Each record details specific licenses, including the license number, business name, unique identifier, and business category, such as "Sightseeing Guide" or "Secondhand Dealer." The dataset also specifies the license type (Individual or Premises) and its current status (Active, Expired, etc.). Key date fields include the license creation and expiration dates, enabling users to track licensing timelines. Address information, including city, state, and zip code, allows for geographic analysis of licensed businesses. Researchers, entrepreneurs, and city planners can leverage this data to understand business trends, identify licensing needs, and analyze the geographic distribution of various business types across the city. The inclusion of contact phone numbers, where available, can facilitate direct engagement with licensed businesses.

title: Tax Lien Sale Lists
ufd: This dataset contains a list of properties in New York City that are potentially eligible for inclusion in an upcoming tax lien sale. It includes properties with outstanding tax and/or water liens. The data provides details such as the borough, block, and lot number for each property, along with its tax class code and building class. Key columns include 'borough', 'block', 'lot', 'street_name', and 'zip_code', which together pinpoint the location of the property. The 'water_debt_only' column indicates whether the lien is solely due to water debt. This dataset could be used by real estate investors to identify potential investment opportunities, or by city officials to manage and track properties with outstanding debts. The 'cycle' column indicates the stage of notification, such as a "90 Day Notice".
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset details properties in New York City that are candidates for a tax lien sale due to outstanding tax and/or water liens. It provides property-specific information like borough, block, lot, street name, and zip code, along with details on tax and building classifications. A key indicator is whether the lien is solely due to water debt.

**Related Topics:**

- Urban Planning
- Debt Management
- New York City Government

- Lien: Encumbrance, Claim, Debt

- Predicting the likelihood of properties entering tax lien sales.

- Understanding the distribution of different property and building classes subject to tax liens.

title: 2023 Yellow Taxi Trip Data
ufd: This dataset contains trip records from yellow taxis in 2023. Each row represents a single taxi trip, including details about pick-up and drop-off times and locations. You can identify the taxi company using the `vendorid`, and pinpoint the start and end of the journey with `tpep_pickup_datetime` and `tpep_dropoff_datetime`. The `pulocationid` and `dolocationid` columns specify the pickup and drop-off zones. Key information such as `trip_distance`, `fare_amount`, `tip_amount`, and `total_amount` are also included, providing a comprehensive overview of the trip cost. Researchers and analysts can use this data to study taxi usage patterns, analyze fare structures, or investigate the impact of congestion on trip costs. The `passenger_count` column allows for analysis of ridership, while `payment_type` indicates payment preferences.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed trip information for yellow taxis in 2023. It includes pickup and drop-off locations and times, fare details, payment types, and passenger counts for each trip. The data allows for analysis of taxi usage patterns, fare structures, and ridership trends.

title: TLC Approved LabCorp Patient Services Drug Test Locations
ufd: This dataset contains a list of TLC-approved LabCorp patient service locations for drug testing. Each entry includes the address, city, state, and postcode of the location. Landmarks provide additional context for the location. The dataset also includes geographic information such as borough name, community board, council district, and census tract, offering insights into the location's surroundings. You can use this dataset to find nearby drug test locations or analyze the distribution of these facilities across different areas. The data is current as of October 8, 2025. Contact tlccompliance@tlc.nyc.gov for inquiries.

title: Primary Land Use Tax Lot Output (PLUTO)
ufd: This dataset, known as PLUTO (Primary Land Use Tax Lot Output), provides detailed land use and geographic information for tax lots in New York City. It includes over 70 fields derived from various city agencies, offering a comprehensive view of properties. Key columns include 'borough', 'block', and 'lot' to uniquely identify properties, along with location information like 'zipcode', 'policeprct', and 'healtharea'. The dataset also contains details on building characteristics such as 'yearbuilt', 'numfloors', 'bldgarea', and land use codes. Researchers, city planners, and real estate professionals can use this data to analyze land use patterns, assess property values, and understand the built environment in NYC. The data can also be used to identify properties within specific school districts ('schooldist') or council districts ('council'). This dataset is updated to version 25v3 and previous versions are available on the DCP website.
sfd:

title: 2018 Central Park Squirrel Census - Squirrel Data
ufd: This dataset contains information on squirrel sightings in Central Park during 2018, collected by The Squirrel Census. Each row represents a unique squirrel sighting, identified by a unique squirrel ID. Key details include the location of the sighting (x, y coordinates and hectare), the time of day (shift), and the date. The dataset also provides information about the squirrel's physical characteristics, such as primary and highlight fur color, and age. Furthermore, the dataset captures the squirrel's behavior, including activities like running, chasing, climbing, eating, and foraging, as well as interactions with other squirrels or humans. Researchers or park enthusiasts can use this data to analyze squirrel behavior patterns, population density in different areas of the park, or the impact of human activity on squirrel behavior.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

title: NYPD Shooting Incident Data (Historic)
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed record of shooting incidents in New York City, dating back to 2006. Each entry represents a single incident and includes the date and time it occurred, the borough and specific location, and whether it was classified as a statistical murder. Information on the individuals involved, such as age group, sex, and race of both perpetrators and victims, is also included where available. The dataset also includes geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude) for mapping and spatial analysis. Researchers, policymakers, and the public can use this data to analyze trends in shooting incidents, understand demographic patterns, and inform public safety strategies. The incident_key serves as a unique identifier for each event, while occur_date and occur_time pinpoint when the incident took place.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains records of shooting incidents in New York City from 2006 to the present. It includes details on the location, date, time, and demographics of victims and perpetrators involved in each incident. title: Parks Properties
ufd: This dataset provides information about properties managed by NYC Parks, including parks, playgrounds, and gardens. Each record represents an acquisition of land by NYC Parks. Key columns include the acquisition date, the size of the property in acres, the address, and the borough in which it is located. The dataset also includes community board and council district information. You can use this dataset to explore the distribution of park properties across the city, analyze the size and location of different types of recreational spaces, or identify properties within specific political districts. The data also includes a multipolygon column with coordinate information for mapping.
sfd:

title: DOB Violations
ufd: This dataset contains information on older civil penalties (DOB Violations) issued by the Department of Buildings (DOB). Each row represents a specific violation, identified by a unique `isn_dob_bis_viol` number. Key details include the `boro` (borough), `block`, and `lot` where the violation occurred, along with the `issue_date` and `violation_type_code`. The `violation_number`, `house_number`, and `street` provide further location context. The `disposition_comments` and `disposition_date` offer insights into the resolution of the violation. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze historical violation patterns, identify areas with frequent violations, and assess the effectiveness of past enforcement efforts. Note that some violations may be duplicated in both this dataset and the DOB Safety Violations dataset.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

Each record represents a specific violation, identified by a unique `isn_dob_bis_viol` number, and includes information on the location, date, and type of violation. title: Parking Violations Issued - Fiscal Year 2024
ufd: This dataset contains information on parking violations issued in New York City during fiscal year 2024 (July 1, 2023 to June 30, 2024). Each row represents a single parking ticket. Key details include the `summons_number` (a unique identifier for the ticket), the `plate_id` and `registration_state` of the vehicle, the `issue_date` and `violation_time`, and the `violation_code` explaining the reason for the ticket. The `street_name` and related street code columns provide location information. You can use this data to analyze parking violation patterns, identify areas with high violation rates, or study the types of vehicles that receive the most tickets. Keep in mind that this dataset only reflects the status of the violation at the time it was issued and does not include updates on payments or dismissals.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

title: New York City Population by Borough, 1950 - 2040
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed look at the population of New York City and its boroughs from 1950 to 2040. It includes both historical census data (1950-2000) and projected figures (2010-2040). The key columns include the borough name, population counts for each decade, and the borough's percentage share of the total NYC population. The 'age_group' column specifies the demographic being counted, such as the total population. This dataset could be used to analyze population trends in NYC, understand the changing demographics of each borough, and inform policy decisions related to resource allocation and urban planning. Researchers, city planners, and policymakers can use this data to gain insights into the past, present, and future population distribution across the city. The projections allow for proactive planning to accommodate future population shifts.
sfd:

title: New York City Leading Causes of Death
ufd: This dataset provides insights into the leading causes of death in New York City for the year 2021. It breaks down mortality data by sex and race/ethnicity, offering a detailed view of health trends within the city. Key columns include "leading_cause," which specifies the primary reason for death, "deaths," representing the number of deaths attributed to that cause, and "death_rate" and "age_adjusted_death_rate," which provide mortality rates. Researchers and public health officials can use this data to identify prevalent health issues, understand disparities in mortality rates across different demographic groups, and inform public health interventions. The dataset also includes the "year," "sex," and "race_ethnicity" columns for filtering and analyzing specific population segments. Understanding these trends can help allocate resources effectively and develop targeted prevention strategies.

title: Traffic Volume Counts
ufd: This dataset contains traffic volume counts collected by the New York City Department of Transportation (NYC DOT) using Automated Traffic Recorders (ATR) at various bridge crossings and roadways. The data includes the `roadway_name`, the `from` and `to` locations defining the segment, and the `direction` of travel. Traffic volume is recorded hourly, from `_12_00_1_00_am` to `_11_00_12_00am`, along with the `date` of the recording. The `segmentid` column provides a unique identifier for each road segment. This dataset can be used to analyze traffic patterns, identify peak hours, and understand traffic flow on different roadways in New York City. Note that data is only available for a limited number of days per location and may vary from year to year. Researchers, urban planners, and transportation engineers can leverage this data for traffic management, infrastructure planning, and transportation modeling.
sfd:

title: NYC Building Energy and Water Data Disclosure for Local Law 84 (2022-Present)
ufd: This dataset contains energy and water consumption data for buildings in New York City, collected to comply with Local Law 84. The data includes property details such as name, address, and primary property type, along with energy-related information like energy star score, site energy use, and greenhouse gas emissions. Water usage data is also provided. The `report_year` column indicates the year the data was reported, while `property_id` uniquely identifies each property. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze building energy performance, track progress towards sustainability goals, and identify opportunities for energy efficiency improvements. The dataset also includes location information like city and postal code for spatial analysis.

title: Affordable Housing Production by Building
ufd: This dataset provides details on affordable housing projects in New York City, specifically those contributing to the Housing New York and Housing Our Neighbors plans since 2014. Each row represents a building within a project, identified by a unique `building_id` and associated with a `project_id` and `project_name`. Key information includes the `project_start_date`, the building's address components (`house_number`, `street_name`, `borough`, `postcode`), and its location within administrative areas like `community_board` and `council_district`. The dataset also breaks down the number of units by income level (`extremely_low_income_units`, `very_low_income_units`, `low_income_units`) and bedroom count (`_1_br_units`, `_2_br_units`, etc.), along with the total number of affordable units (`total_units`). Researchers, city planners, and housing advocates can use this data to analyze affordable housing production trends, assess the distribution of affordable units across different boroughs and income levels, and evaluate the impact of housing policies. Information on construction type (`reporting_construction_type`), affordability status (`extended_affordability_status`), and prevailing wage status (`prevailing_wage_status`) offers further insights into the nature and quality of these projects.
sfd:

title: DOB ECB Violations
ufd: This dataset contains information on summonses issued by the New York City Department of Buildings (DOB) and adjudicated by the Office of Administrative Trials and Hearings (OATH)/Environmental Control Board (ECB). Each row represents a single violation, identified by a unique ECB violation number. Key details include the Building Identification Number (BIN), borough, block, and lot where the violation occurred, as well as the date and time of the hearing. The dataset also specifies the type and severity of the violation, the penalty imposed, the amount paid, and any balance due. You can use this data to analyze trends in building code violations across different boroughs, assess the effectiveness of enforcement efforts, or identify properties with repeated violations. The `ecb_violation_status` column indicates the current status of the violation, while `hearing_status` details the outcome of the hearing.

title: EMS Incident Dispatch Data
ufd: This dataset contains information about EMS incident dispatches, from the initial call to the closing of the incident. It includes details on the type of call (e.g., injury, drug-related), the severity level, and timestamps for various stages of the response, such as when the incident was first assigned, when responders arrived on the scene, and when the patient arrived at the hospital. The dataset also provides information on the location of the incident, including the borough, dispatch area, and zip code. Key columns include `incident_datetime`, `initial_call_type`, `final_call_type`, `dispatch_response_seconds_qy` (dispatch response time in seconds), and geographic information. Researchers and public safety analysts can use this data to analyze response times, identify trends in incident types, and assess resource allocation across different areas. The `held_indicator` and `reopen_indicator` columns can be used to understand incident management processes. Please note that to protect personal information, specific locations have been aggregated.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details EMS incident dispatches, encompassing the entire incident lifecycle from initial call to closure. It includes information on call types, severity levels, timestamps for response stages (dispatch, arrival, hospital arrival), and location details (borough, dispatch area, zip code). The data allows for analysis of response times, incident trends, and resource allocation.

title: Modified Zip Code Tabulation Areas (MODZCTA)
ufd: This dataset provides geographic boundaries for Modified Zip Code Tabulation Areas (MODZCTA) in New York City. MODZCTAs are a custom geographic aggregation of zip codes used by the NYC Department of Health & Mental Hygiene (DOHMH) for mapping health-related data, particularly for COVID-19 analysis. The dataset includes the MODZCTA code, a label, the corresponding 2010 Census ZCTA(s), and a population estimate. The `the_geom` column contains the geospatial data defining the boundaries of each MODZCTA. Researchers and public health officials can use this dataset to visualize and analyze health data at the MODZCTA level, identify areas with specific health needs, and inform public health interventions. The population estimates can be used to calculate rates and per capita measures.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains geographic boundaries for Modified Zip Code Tabulation Areas (MODZCTA) in New York City. MODZCTAs are custom geographic aggregations of zip codes used by the NYC DOHMH for health data mapping, especially for COVID-19 analysis. The dataset includes MODZCTA codes, labels, corresponding 2010 Census ZCTAs, population estimates, and geospatial data.

title: Street Hail Livery (SHL) Drivers - Active
ufd: This dataset contains information about active, licensed Street Hail Livery (SHL) drivers in New York City. Each row represents a driver and includes their license number, name, status, and license expiration date. The `license_number` is a unique identifier for each driver, and the `name` column provides the driver's name. The `status_description` indicates the driver's current status, which is "SHL UNRESTRICTED" for all entries in this sample, meaning they are authorized to operate SHL vehicles. The `expiration_date` shows when the driver's license expires. This dataset is updated daily, with the `last_update_date` and `last_update_time` reflecting the most recent update. You can use this dataset to verify the status of SHL drivers or analyze license expiration trends.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides details on active, licensed Street Hail Livery (SHL) drivers in New York City. It includes information such as license number, driver name, license status (currently "SHL UNRESTRICTED" for all entries), and license expiration date. The dataset is updated daily, offering a current snapshot of SHL driver licensing.

title: BUILDING
ufd: This dataset provides detailed information about building footprints in New York City, offering insights into the city's built environment. Each row represents a building footprint, with its geometry described in the `the_geom` column, allowing for spatial analysis. Key attributes include the building identification number (`bin`), Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications ID (`doitt_id`), the building's base BBL (`base_bbl`) and its construction year (`construction_year`). The `shape_area` and `shape_length` columns provide measurements of the building footprint. Additional data includes the source of the geometry (`geom_source`), ground elevation (`ground_elevation`), and roof height (`height_roof`). Researchers, urban planners, and developers can use this dataset to analyze building characteristics, assess urban development patterns, and support various city planning initiatives.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains detailed building footprint information for New York City. It includes geometric data, unique identifiers, construction year, and measurements like area and length for each building. The data allows for spatial analysis and understanding of the city's built environment.

title: City Record Online
ufd: This dataset provides a searchable database of notices published in the City Record newspaper. It includes information on public hearings and meetings, auctions and sales, solicitations and awards, and official rules proposed and adopted by city agencies. Key columns include `request_id`, `start_date`, `end_date`, `agency_name`, `short_title`, and `section_name`. The `agency_name` column indicates the specific city agency involved, while `short_title` and `section_name` describe the type of notice. The `additional_description_1` column provides further details, such as effective dates, job titles, and salary information for personnel changes. Researchers and the public can use this dataset to track city government activities, monitor personnel changes, and identify procurement opportunities. The dataset also contains contact information for specific notices, such as phone numbers and email addresses.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains a comprehensive record of notices published in the City Record, offering insights into the inner workings of city government. It includes details on public hearings, auctions, solicitations, rule changes, and personnel actions across various city agencies. Users can search and filter by agency, notice type, date, and keywords to track specific government activities and opportunities.

title: Property Valuation and Assessment Data
ufd: This dataset contains property valuation and assessment data for properties in New York City, collected by the Department of Finance. It includes information used to calculate property tax bills. Key columns include 'boro' (borough), 'block', 'lot', 'owner', 'bldgcl' (building class), and 'taxclass'. The dataset also provides details on lot dimensions ('ltfront', 'ltdepth'), building characteristics ('stories'), and property values ('fullval', 'avland', 'avtot'). Researchers, city planners, and real estate professionals can use this data to analyze property values, understand tax assessments, and gain insights into land use patterns in NYC. The data covers the assessment period of 2018/19.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed property valuation and assessment information for properties in New York City during the 2018/19 assessment period. Compiled by the Department of Finance, it includes key data points like borough, block, lot, building class, tax class, property dimensions, building characteristics, and assessed values. This data is crucial for understanding property tax calculations and land use patterns across the city.

title: NYPD Calls for Service (Year to Date)
ufd: This dataset contains information about calls for service to the NYPD's 911 system, documenting each entry into the ICAD system. It includes details on incidents reported by the public and self-initiated entries by NYPD personnel. Key columns include `incident_date` and `incident_time`, specifying when the incident occurred, `nypd_pct_cd` indicating the police precinct, and `boro_nm` representing the borough where the incident took place. The `typ_desc` column provides a description of the incident type, while `latitude` and `longitude` offer geographic coordinates. Researchers and public safety analysts can use this data to analyze incident trends, response times, and resource allocation across different areas of New York City. The dataset also includes timestamps for when the call was added (`add_ts`), dispatched (`disp_ts`), when officers arrived (`arrivd_ts`), and when the incident was closed (`closng_ts`).
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details calls for service to the NYPD 911 system, capturing incidents reported by the public and self-initiated actions by NYPD personnel. It includes information on incident type, location (borough, precinct, latitude, longitude), and timestamps for key stages like call addition, dispatch, arrival, and closure. Researchers and analysts can use this data to study crime patterns, response times, and resource allocation within New York City.

Related Topics:

- Assess the impact of public safety initiatives on crime rates.

title: 2021 Yellow Taxi Trip Data
ufd: This dataset contains trip records for yellow taxis in 2021. Each row represents a single taxi trip, including details about pick-up and drop-off times and locations. You can identify the taxi company using the `vendorid` and the specific pick-up and drop-off zones via `pulocationid` and `dolocationid`, respectively. The dataset also provides information on the number of passengers (`passenger_count`) and the distance traveled (`trip_distance`). Furthermore, it breaks down the fare into different components such as `fare_amount`, `tip_amount`, `tolls_amount`, and other surcharges, culminating in the `total_amount`. Researchers and analysts can use this data to study taxi ridership patterns, analyze fare structures, or build predictive models for trip demand. The `store_and_fwd_flag` indicates if the trip record was temporarily stored in the vehicle before being sent to the vendor.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed trip information for yellow taxis in 2021. It includes pick-up and drop-off locations and times, passenger count, trip distance, and a breakdown of fare components. The data allows for analysis of taxi ridership patterns and fare structures.

- DOLocationID: Drop-off location ID

- Fare Amount: Base fare
- Tip Amount: Gratuity
- Total Amount: Total fare including all charges
- Store and Forward Flag: Data transmission delay indicator

Applications and Use Cases:

- Study the impact of tolls and surcharges on taxi fares.
- Identify popular pick-up and drop-off locations.
- Build a model to estimate trip costs.

title: Popular Baby Names
ufd: This dataset provides insights into the popularity of baby names in 2021. Specifically, it focuses on female names within the Asian and Pacific Islander ethnic group. Each row represents a unique name and its corresponding count, indicating how many times that name was registered. The 'rnk' column shows the popularity rank of each name, with lower numbers indicating higher popularity. Researchers and parents can use this data to explore naming trends and identify popular names within this demographic. The dataset includes the birth year ('brth_yr'), gender ('gndr'), ethnicity ('ethcty'), name ('nm'), count ('cnt'), and rank ('rnk'). Be mindful when interpreting ranks with low frequency counts, as these can fluctuate.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the popularity of female baby names within the Asian and Pacific Islander ethnic group in 2021. It includes the name, count of occurrences, and popularity rank for each name. The data allows for analysis of naming trends and identification of common names within this specific demographic.

- Developing resources for expectant parents seeking name ideas.
- Studying the cultural significance of names within the API community.

title: Emergency Response Incidents
ufd: This dataset contains information about emergency response incidents. It includes the type of incident (e.g., Utility-Water Main, Fire-2nd Alarm), the location as a street address, and the borough where the incident occurred. The dataset also provides the date and time the incident was created, along with latitude and longitude coordinates. The 'incident_type' column categorizes the emergency, while 'location' and 'borough' specify where it happened. The 'creation_date' indicates when the incident was reported. This data could be used to analyze the types and locations of emergencies, identify trends, and improve resource allocation for emergency services. Note that the 'closed_date' column has mostly missing values.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details emergency response incidents, including the incident type, location (street address and borough), and creation date/time. Latitude and longitude coordinates are also provided for each incident. The data can be used to analyze emergency trends and improve resource allocation.

title: Street Closures due to construction activities by Block
ufd: This dataset provides information on street closures in New York City due to construction activities. It includes the location of the street closure as a geographic feature (`the_geom`), the street name where the closure occurs (`onstreetname`), and the intersecting streets that define the closed segment (`fromstreetname`, `tostreetname`). The dataset also specifies the borough (`borough_code`) where the closure is located. Key temporal information includes the start and end dates of the work causing the closure (`work_start_date`, `work_end_date`). The `purpose` column describes the type of construction activity taking place. This data can be used to understand the impact of construction on traffic flow, plan alternative routes, or analyze the frequency and duration of street closures in different boroughs. The `segmentid` and `uniqueid` columns can be used to uniquely identify each street closure segment.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details street closures in New York City resulting from construction. It includes geographic location, street names (closed street and intersecting streets), borough, start and end dates of the work, and the purpose of the construction. The data allows for analysis of construction impact on traffic and street closure patterns.

title: Motor Vehicle Collisions - Vehicles
ufd: This dataset contains information about motor vehicle collisions in NYC, with each row representing a vehicle involved in a crash. Key details include the crash date and time, the type of vehicle, and the state registration. You can also find contributing factors to the collision. The dataset provides a unique ID for each vehicle and the corresponding collision ID. This data could be used to analyze trends in vehicle collisions, identify common contributing factors, or assess the types of vehicles most frequently involved in accidents. The 'travel_direction', 'pre_crash', and 'point_of_impact' columns offer insights into the circumstances surrounding the collisions. Note that some columns, such as vehicle make and year, have a high percentage of missing values.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details motor vehicle collisions in New York City, with each record representing a vehicle involved in a crash. It includes information on the crash date and time, vehicle type, state registration, and contributing factors. Unique identifiers for both the vehicle and the collision are provided.

title: DOB Certificate Of Occupancy
ufd: This dataset contains information on Certificates of Occupancy (CO) issued by the New York City Department of Buildings (DOB) from July 2012 to March 2021. A Certificate of Occupancy states a building’s legal use and type of permitted occupancy. Each row represents a specific CO, identified by a unique job number. Key details include the job type (e.g., A1 or NB), the date the CO was issued, the borough where the property is located, and the building identification number (BIN). You can also find the house number, street name, block, lot, and postcode for the property. This dataset could be used to analyze trends in building occupancy, assess housing development patterns across different boroughs, or examine the timeline of CO issuances for specific properties. The dataset also includes geographic information such as latitude, longitude, community board, council district, and census tract.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details Certificates of Occupancy (CO) issued by the NYC DOB from July 2012 to March 2021. Each record represents a unique CO, identified by job number, and includes information on the property's legal use, occupancy type, location, and issuance date. title: New York City Population By Community Districts
ufd: This dataset contains population figures for New York City community districts from 1970 to 2010, collected from the Census Bureau. Each row represents a community district, identified by its borough (e.g., Bronx, Brooklyn), a community district number, and a descriptive name. The dataset includes population counts for each district for the census years 1970, 1980, 1990, 2000, and 2010. This data can be used to analyze population trends and demographic changes within different community districts over time. Researchers, city planners, and policymakers can leverage this information for urban development, resource allocation, and understanding the evolving needs of different neighborhoods. The data was compiled by the Population Division of the New York City Department of City Planning.

title: Water Consumption in the City of New York
ufd: This dataset provides a historical record of water consumption in New York City, offering insights into the city's water usage patterns over time. It includes data from 1960 to 2024, detailing the city's population, total water consumption in millions of gallons per day, and per capita water consumption. The 'year' column indicates the year of the data, while 'new_york_city_population' represents the population count for that year. 'nyc_consumption_million_gallons_per_day' shows the total water consumed, and 'per_capita_gallons_per_person_per_day' calculates the average water usage per person. Researchers, urban planners, and environmental scientists can use this data to analyze trends in water consumption, understand the relationship between population and water demand, and develop strategies for sustainable water management in urban environments. The dataset can also be used to forecast future water needs and assess the impact of conservation efforts.
sfd:

title: NYPD Hate Crimes
ufd: This dataset contains records of confirmed hate crimes in New York City. Each row represents a single complaint, identified by a unique `full_complaint_id`. The data includes the year and month of the complaint (`complaint_year_number`, `month_number`), as well as the date the record was created (`record_create_date`). Location information is provided through the `complaint_precinct_code`, `patrol_borough_name`, and `county` columns. Details about the offense are captured in columns like `law_code_category_description`, `offense_description`, and `pd_code_description`. The `bias_motive_description` column specifies the motive behind the hate crime, and `offense_category` provides a general classification of the crime. This dataset could be used to analyze trends in hate crimes over time and across different locations in NYC, understand the types of offenses being committed, and identify the motivations behind these crimes. The dataset is limited to Anti-Jewish hate crimes in Brooklyn South.
sfd:

Each record represents a single complaint and includes information on the date, location (precinct, borough, county), offense details (law code, offense description, PD code), bias motive, and offense category. The data spans multiple years and can be used to analyze trends and patterns in Anti-Jewish hate crimes within Brooklyn South.

title: CURRENT BASES
ufd: This dataset provides information on current For-Hire Vehicle (FHV) bases in New York City. Each row represents a unique base and includes details such as the license number, entity name, telephone number, and physical address (building, street, city, state, and zip code). The `type_of_base` column specifies the type of service offered, such as "Livery Base," "Black Car Base," or "Luxury/Limousine." Location data is also provided in the form of latitude and longitude coordinates. The dataset also includes computed region identifiers. You can use this dataset to identify and locate FHV bases, analyze their distribution across the city, or examine the prevalence of different base types. Note that the dataset provides a link to the official NYC website for the most up-to-date information.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information about For-Hire Vehicle (FHV) bases operating in New York City. It includes details on each base's license, name, contact information, address, and geographic coordinates. The dataset also specifies the type of service offered by each base (e.g., Livery, Black Car).

title: Recent Contract Awards
ufd: This dataset contains information on recent contract awards by New York City agencies. It's a record of the City's procurement activities, managed by the Office of Citywide Procurement. Key details include the agency making the award (`agency_name`), the type and category of service or goods being contracted (`type_of_notice_description`, `category_description`), and a brief description of the contract (`short_title`). The dataset also provides the start and end dates of the award, the method used for selecting the vendor (`selection_method_description`), and the contract amount (`contract_amount`). You can use this data to understand which agencies are awarding contracts, the types of services being procured, and the monetary value of these contracts. Contact information for each award, such as contact name and email, is also provided. This information can be valuable for businesses seeking to work with the City, as well as for citizens interested in government spending and procurement practices.
sfd:

title: Fire Incident Dispatch Data
ufd: This dataset contains information about fire incidents in New York City, as recorded by the Starfire Computer Aided Dispatch System. Each row represents a unique incident, identified by a `starfire_incident_id`, and includes the date and time the incident occurred (`incident_datetime`). The data provides details on the location of the incident, including the `alarm_box_borough`, `alarm_box_number`, and `alarm_box_location`, as well as broader geographic information like `zipcode`, `policeprecinct`, and `citycouncildistrict`. You can explore the nature of the incidents through the `incident_classification` and `incident_classification_group` columns, and understand the severity using `alarm_level_index_description` and `highest_alarm_level`. The dataset also tracks response times, such as `dispatch_response_seconds_qy` and `incident_response_seconds_qy`, along with the number of engines, ladders, and other units assigned. Researchers and public safety analysts can use this data to analyze incident patterns, evaluate response times, and optimize resource allocation. The data spans from incident creation to closure, offering a comprehensive view of the Fire Department's response to emergencies.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

title: COVID-19 Daily Counts of Cases, Hospitalizations, and Deaths
ufd: This dataset provides daily COVID-19 statistics for New York City residents. It includes the daily counts of positive cases (both confirmed and probable), hospitalizations, and deaths. You can also find the 7-day averages for these metrics, offering a smoothed view of trends. The data is broken down by borough (Bronx, Brooklyn, Manhattan, Queens, and Staten Island), allowing for granular analysis of the pandemic's impact across the city. The `date_of_interest` column indicates the day for which the data is reported. Researchers and public health officials can use this dataset to track the spread of COVID-19, assess the effectiveness of interventions, and understand the burden on the healthcare system.
sfd:

title: Property Tax Rates by Tax Class
ufd: This dataset provides a table of property tax rates by tax class for a city government. It includes tax rates for four different classes of property (class_1, class_2, class_3, and class_4) across different years. The 'year' column indicates the tax year for which the rates apply. Each of the class columns (class_1 through class_4) represents the tax rate for that specific property class. This dataset could be used to analyze trends in property tax rates over time for different property types. City planners, residents, or real estate professionals might find this information useful for understanding the local tax landscape. The dataset contains 28 rows, spanning different tax years.
sfd:

title: Sidewalk Management Database - Violations
ufd: This dataset contains information on sidewalk violations in New York City, managed through the Sidewalk Management System. It tracks inspections, violations, and the status of sidewalks. Key columns include `violationid`, a unique identifier for each violation, and address information split across columns like `house_num`, `frstname` (street name from), and `tostname` (street name to). Several date fields are present, such as `vissuedate` (violation issued date), `certi_date` (certification date), `vdismissdate` (violation dismissal date), `post_date` (posting date) and `entrydate` (date of entry). The dataset also includes flags indicating specific sidewalk defects like `broken` sidewalks or `trip_haz`ards. The `contract` column identifies the contract associated with the violation. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze sidewalk conditions, track violation trends, and improve sidewalk maintenance strategies.
sfd:
