title: Parking Meters Locations and Status
ufd: This dataset provides information on the locations and status of parking meters in New York City. Each record represents a single parking meter and includes details such as its meter number, current status (active or inactive), and pay-by-cell number. The dataset also specifies the hours of operation for each meter, the type of facility (on-street or off-street), and the borough in which it is located. Location information is provided through street names, side of the street, intersecting streets, latitude, and longitude. Computed regions are also included for more granular geographic analysis. This data can be used to analyze parking availability, identify areas with high meter utilization, or investigate parking meter issues.
sfd:

title: Property Valuation and Assessment Data Tax Classes 1,2,3,4
ufd: This dataset contains property valuation and assessment data for New York City, specifically focusing on tax classes 1, 2, 3, and 4. It includes information used to calculate property taxes and grant exemptions or abatements. Key columns include `boro` (borough), `block`, `lot`, `year` (assessment year), `pymktland` (previous year market land value), `pymkttot` (previous year total market value), and `pytaxclass` (previous year tax class). The dataset also provides details on building class (`bldg_class`), owner, and zoning. Researchers, city planners, and real estate professionals can use this data to analyze property values, understand tax burdens, and assess property characteristics across the city. The data is collected and entered by various city employees, including property assessors and exemption specialists.
sfd:

title: 2020 Census Tracts
ufd: This dataset contains geographic and demographic information for the 2020 Census Tracts in New York City. It includes the geometry of each census tract, represented in the `the_geom` column, allowing for spatial analysis and mapping. Key columns include `ctlabel` and `ct2020`, which are identifiers for the census tract. The dataset also provides the borough code (`borocode`) and borough name (`boroname`) for each tract, along with neighborhood information in the `ntaname` and `nta2020` columns. Community district information is available in the `cdta2020` and `cdtaname` columns. Researchers, city planners, and the public can use this dataset to analyze population distribution, understand neighborhood characteristics, and support decision-making related to resource allocation and urban development within New York City. The `cdeligibil` column indicates eligibility, potentially for specific programs or funding.
sfd:

title: NYC Permitted Event Information
ufd: This dataset provides information on permitted events in New York City, offering a glimpse into the city's vibrant event landscape. Each row represents a specific event, identified by a unique `event_id` and described by its `event_name`. The dataset includes the `start_date_time` and `end_date_time` of the event, as well as the `event_agency` responsible for the event. You can find out what type of event it is via the `event_type` column (e.g., "Sport - Youth", "Special Event", "Farmers Market"). The `event_borough` and `event_location` columns specify where the event is taking place. Additional details include the `community_board` and `police_precinct` associated with the event. This dataset could be used to analyze event trends across different boroughs, understand the types of events that occur most frequently, or plan resources based on event schedules and locations.
sfd:

title: Rodent Inspection
ufd: This dataset contains information about rodent inspections conducted in New York City. Each row represents a single inspection, detailing the location, type of inspection, and the result. Key columns include `inspection_type`, indicating whether it was an initial inspection, a follow-up ("BAIT"), or a compliance check, and `result`, which shows whether the inspection passed or indicated rat activity. Location information is provided through address components like `house_number`, `street_name`, `borough`, and `zip_code`, as well as geographic coordinates. The `job_progress` column tracks the status of the inspection job. Researchers and public health officials can use this data to analyze rat activity patterns across the city, evaluate the effectiveness of pest control measures, and identify areas with the greatest need for intervention. The data also includes several computed region columns that provide additional geographic context.
sfd:

title: Parking Regulation Locations and Signs
ufd: This dataset contains information about parking regulation signs managed by the New York City Department of Transportation. It includes details on the location of these signs, such as the borough, street names, and side of the street. Key columns include `order_number` to identify specific orders, `sign_code` and `sign_description` to understand the parking regulation, and `order_completed_on_date` to track when the sign was installed or updated. The dataset also provides the size of the sign (`sign_size`) and its distance from the nearest intersection. Researchers, city planners, and residents can use this dataset to analyze parking regulations, identify areas with specific signage, and track changes in parking policies over time. The geographic coordinates (`sign_x_coord`, `sign_y_coord`) allow for spatial analysis and mapping of parking regulations.

title: TLC New Driver Application Status
ufd: This dataset provides the status of new TLC (Taxi and Limousine Commission) driver license applications. Updated frequently, it allows applicants to check the progress of their application. Key columns include the application number (`app_no`), the application date (`app_date`), and the current status (`status`), indicating whether the application is incomplete, approved, denied, or under review. The dataset also tracks the completion status of required items such as the drug test, WAV course, defensive driving course, driver exam, and medical clearance form. Additional requirements, like fingerprints or a copy of the DMV license, are listed in the `other_requirements` column. The `lastupdate` column shows the timestamp of the last update to the dataset. Users can leverage this data to monitor their application's progress and identify any outstanding requirements. This dataset focuses solely on "HDR" type applications.

title: Property Exemption Detail
ufd: This dataset provides detailed information on property tax exemptions in New York City, as maintained by the Department of Finance. It covers exemptions for government, not-for-profit, and commercial properties. Key columns include `boro` (borough), `block`, and `lot`, which together uniquely identify a property. The `exmp_code` and `nys_exmp_code` columns specify the type of exemption applied to the property, while columns like `pyexmptot`, `tenexmptot`, and `curexmptot` detail the total exemption amounts for previous, current, and cured tax years, respectively. Researchers, city planners, and property owners can use this data to analyze trends in property tax exemptions, assess the fiscal impact of these exemptions, and understand the distribution of benefits across different property types and boroughs. The `exname` column provides the name of the exempt entity. The dataset includes information from 2024 and earlier.

title: DHS Daily Report
ufd: This dataset provides a daily snapshot of the number of individuals and families residing in Department of Homeless Services (DHS) shelters. The dataset includes a daily census date, along with counts of total adults, children, and individuals in shelters. It further breaks down the adult population into single men and women, and provides counts of families with children, including the number of adults and children within those families. Researchers and policy makers can use this data to analyze trends in shelter populations, understand the composition of individuals and families seeking shelter, and inform resource allocation strategies. The dataset contains 100 rows with data from late 2025. Key metrics include `total_adults_in_shelter`, `total_children_in_shelter`, and `families_with_children_in_shelter`.

title: Street Construction Permits (2022-Present)
ufd: This dataset contains information on street construction permits issued by the DOT from 2022 to the present. Each row represents a unique permit, identified by its `permitnumber` and `applicationtrackingid`. Key details include the type of permit (`permitseriesshortdesc`, `permittypedesc`), its status (`permitstatusshortdesc`), and the dates it was issued and valid (`permitissuedate`, `issuedworkstartdate`, `issuedworkenddate`). The data also provides location information, including the borough (`boroughname`) and street names (`onstreetname`, `fromstreetname`, `tostreetname`). The `permitteename` column indicates the organization or individual who was granted the permit. Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to analyze construction activity, track permit trends, and assess the impact of construction on city streets and infrastructure. The `specificstipulations` column may contain additional conditions or requirements associated with the permit.

title: Bus Breakdown and Delays
ufd: This dataset provides real-time information about NYC school bus breakdowns and delays, as reported by bus vendors. It includes details such as the school year, bus number, route, and reason for the delay (e.g., heavy traffic, mechanical problems). The `run_type` column specifies whether the bus run is for general education, special education, or pre-K/early intervention. Key columns also indicate whether schools and parents were notified and if the Office of Pupil Transportation (OPT) was alerted. You can use this data to analyze trends in bus delays, identify common reasons for breakdowns, and assess the effectiveness of communication protocols. The `occurred_on` and `created_on` columns provide timestamps for when the delay occurred and when it was reported. The dataset also includes the bus company name, the number of students on the bus, and the borough where the incident occurred.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains real-time information on NYC school bus breakdowns and delays, as reported by bus vendors. It includes details about the bus route, reason for delay, school year, and notification status. The data can be used to analyze delay trends, identify common causes, and assess communication effectiveness.

title: Motor Vehicle Collisions - Person
ufd: This dataset contains information about people involved in motor vehicle collisions in New York City, starting from April 2016. Each row represents a person involved in a crash, detailing their role (driver, occupant, pedestrian, or bicyclist), any injuries sustained, and demographic information like age and sex. Key columns include `crash_date` and `crash_time` for when the incident occurred, `person_type` to identify the person's role, and `person_injury` to describe the extent of injuries. The dataset also includes details about the vehicle involved (`vehicle_id`) and contributing factors to the crash. Researchers and public safety analysts can use this data to identify trends in traffic accidents, understand factors contributing to injuries, and develop strategies for improving road safety. The data can also be used to analyze the effectiveness of safety equipment and identify high-risk populations or locations.

title: New York City Population By Neighborhood Tabulation Areas
ufd: This dataset provides population figures for New York City, broken down by Neighborhood Tabulation Areas (NTAs). NTAs are aggregations of census tracts and subsets of Public Use Microdata Areas, and may not perfectly represent neighborhoods. The data originates from the Census Bureau's Decennial data. Each row represents a specific NTA in the year 2000. Key columns include 'borough' indicating the borough the NTA is located in, 'nta_code' and 'nta_name' which provide a unique identifier and name for each neighborhood tabulation area, and 'population' which gives the population count for that area. The 'fips_county_code' column provides the FIPS code for the county. This dataset could be used to analyze population distribution across NYC neighborhoods, compare population sizes between different areas, or as a basis for further demographic studies.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset contains population figures for New York City at the Neighborhood Tabulation Area (NTA) level for the year 2000. NTAs are statistical areas created from aggregations of census tracts. The data includes borough, NTA code and name, population count, and FIPS county code for each NTA.

- Combining with other datasets for socio-economic analysis at the neighborhood level.

title: Forestry Tree Points
ufd: This dataset contains records of forestry tree points managed by NYC Parks & Recreation. Each row represents a tree, identified by a unique `objectid` and `globalid`, and includes its location as a point (`geometry`). Key attributes include `genusspecies` which specifies the tree's species, `dbh` (diameter at breast height) indicating the tree's size, `tpstructure` describing the tree's structure (e.g., Full, Retired, Stump), and `tpcondition` assessing the tree's health (e.g., Excellent, Good, Poor, Dead). The dataset also provides information on planting spaces (`plantingspaceglobalid`) and administrative regions. Users can analyze tree distribution, health trends, and species diversity across different areas of NYC. This data can be joined with the Forestry Planting Spaces dataset using `plantingspaceglobalid` to gain a comprehensive view of tree management. The `riskrating` and `riskratingdate` columns provide insights into tree risk assessments.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details individual trees managed by NYC Parks & Recreation, providing location, species, size, and condition information for each tree. It includes attributes like species (`genusspecies`), diameter (`dbh`), structure (`tpstructure`), and health (`tpcondition`). The data also contains risk assessment information and can be linked to planting space data for a more comprehensive view of tree management.

- Risk Rating: Tree hazard assessment, risk evaluation

Applications and Use Cases:

- Track changes in tree populations over time.

title: Bedbug Reporting
ufd: This dataset contains information on bed bug infestation history in New York City properties, as reported annually by property owners. It includes details such as the building's address (borough, house number, street name, and postcode), the number of dwelling units, and counts of infested, eradicated, and re-infested units. The filing date and the period the filing covers are also included. You can use this data to analyze trends in bed bug infestations across different boroughs, identify areas with high infestation rates, and track the effectiveness of eradication efforts. The dataset also provides location information through latitude, longitude, community board, city council district, and neighborhood (NTA), enabling spatial analysis of bed bug incidents. Each record represents a filing completed by a property owner, with the most recent filing considered the active submission for a given period.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

It includes information on property addresses, dwelling unit counts, and infestation statistics (infested, eradicated, and re-infested units). title: NYC Dog Licensing Dataset
ufd: This dataset contains information on active dog licenses in New York City. It includes details such as the dog's name, gender, breed, and birth year. The dataset also provides the zipcode where the dog resides, the date the license was issued, and the license expiration date. The `extract_year` column indicates the year the data was extracted. This data could be used to analyze dog populations by breed and location within NYC. It could also be used to study trends in dog licensing and identify areas with low compliance rates.
sfd:

title: Electric Consumption And Cost (2010 - May 2025)
ufd: This dataset contains monthly electric consumption and cost information for various developments in New York City, spanning from 2010 to May 2025. The data is broken down by borough and development name, allowing users to analyze energy usage patterns in specific areas. Key columns include `consumption_kwh` (kilowatt-hour consumption), `current_charges` (billing charges), `vendor_name` (utility provider), and `funding_source`. The dataset also provides details on meter types (`meter_amr`) and billing IDs (`umis_bill_id`). Researchers and city planners can use this data to understand energy consumption trends, identify areas with high energy costs, and assess the impact of different funding sources on energy efficiency in housing developments. The `revenue_month`, `service_start_date`, and `service_end_date` columns enable time-series analysis of energy consumption.

title: Public Restrooms
ufd: This dataset provides information on public restrooms in New York City, including those in parks and libraries. You can find details such as the facility name, location type (e.g., park, library), and the operating organization. The dataset also indicates the current operational status, availability of changing stations, and accessibility information. Location is specified by latitude and longitude coordinates. Furthermore, you can find details on hours of operation and restroom types (e.g., multi-stall, single-stall all-gender). This information can be used to locate public restrooms, check their accessibility, and determine their hours. Keep in mind that restroom availability may change due to maintenance or other factors.

title: Multiple Dwelling Registrations
ufd: This dataset contains registration information for multiple dwelling units in New York City, specifically focusing on Manhattan in this sample. Collected by the Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD), it includes details about residential rental buildings with three or more units, or one- or two-family homes not occupied by the owner or their family. Key columns include `housenumber`, `streetname`, `zip`, `boro` (borough), `communityboard`, `lastregistrationdate`, and `registrationenddate`. The dataset also provides unique identifiers for each registration (`registrationid`) and building (`buildingid`). Researchers, urban planners, and real estate professionals can use this data to analyze housing trends, track building registration compliance, and understand the distribution of rental properties across Manhattan. The data includes the street code, block, lot, and building identification number (BIN) for precise location analysis.
sfd:

title: Harbor Water Quality
ufd: This dataset contains water quality measurements collected from various locations in a harbor. The data includes information on sampling location, date, and time, along with weather conditions at the time of sampling. Key measurements include temperature, salinity, conductivity, dissolved oxygen, pH, and levels of various nutrients and bacteria at both the top and bottom of the water column. The dataset also provides information on water depth, current speed and direction, wind speed and direction, and sea state. Researchers and environmental managers can use this data to assess water quality trends, identify pollution sources, and monitor the health of the harbor ecosystem. The `sampling_location` column identifies where the samples were taken, while `sample_date` and `sample_time` provide the temporal context for the measurements.
sfd:

This dataset provides comprehensive water quality measurements collected from a harbor, encompassing various locations and time points. It includes physical, chemical, and biological parameters measured at both the top and bottom of the water column, along with weather and environmental conditions. title: 2017-18  - 2021-22 Demographic Snapshot
ufd: This dataset provides a demographic snapshot of New York City public schools from 2017-18 to 2021-22. It includes enrollment counts, broken down by grade level, gender, and race/ethnicity. You can use this data to analyze trends in student demographics over time, identify disparities in enrollment across different groups, and understand the characteristics of students in specific schools. Key columns include 'school_name', 'year', 'total_enrollment', and enrollment counts for various demographic groups. The dataset also contains information on students with disabilities, English language learners, poverty levels, and the Economic Need Index for each school. Note that enrollment counts are based on the October 31 Audited Register, with slight variations in 2020-21 and 2021-22 due to school year delays. Data on students with disabilities, English Language Learners, students' poverty status, and students' Economic Need Value are as of the June 30 for each school year except in 2021-22. Data on SWDs, ELLs, Poverty, and ENI in the 2021-22 school year are as of March 7, 2022.
sfd:

title: Total SNAP Recipients (Historical)
ufd: This dataset provides monthly statistics on the total number of individuals receiving benefits from the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP). The dataset includes two columns: 'month', indicating the month for which the data is recorded, and 'total_snap_recipients', representing the total count of SNAP recipients for that month. Each row represents a unique month, with data spanning 100 months. Researchers and policymakers can use this dataset to analyze trends in SNAP participation over time, understand the impact of economic conditions on program enrollment, and inform decisions related to food security and social welfare programs. The data can be used to track changes in the number of SNAP recipients, identify potential areas of need, and evaluate the effectiveness of SNAP in addressing food insecurity.

title: Civil List
ufd: This dataset provides a snapshot of individuals employed by the City of New York in 2024. It includes details such as the employee's name, the agency they work for (e.g., Police Department, Department of Education), and their salary rate. The 'dpt' column represents the agency code, while 'ttl' refers to the title code associated with the position. 'pc' indicates the pay class of the employee. Researchers or city planners could use this data to analyze salary distributions across different agencies, identify trends in city employment, or gain insights into the workforce composition of various departments. The dataset offers a valuable resource for understanding the financial commitments and personnel structure of New York City's government.

title: J-51 Exemption and Abatement (Historical)
ufd: This dataset contains historical information on J-51 property tax exemptions and abatements in New York City, specifically for tax years prior to 2019. The J-51 program provides tax benefits for the renovation of residential apartment buildings. Key columns include 'block' and 'lot' to identify properties, 'tax_year' indicating the year the data applies to, 'cost_of_alt' representing the cost of alterations, and 'abate_grant' showing the amount of the abatement grant.  The 'exempt_amt' column provides the amount of tax exemption. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze the impact of the J-51 program over time, understand trends in property renovation, and assess the distribution of tax benefits across different properties. Note that more recent J-51 data is available in the Property Exemption Detail and Property Abatement Detail datasets.

title: Open Restaurant Applications (Historic)
ufd: This dataset contains information on Open Restaurant applications in New York City. It includes details such as restaurant names, addresses (building number, street, borough, and zip code), and the type of seating they are interested in (sidewalk, roadway, or open streets). Key columns include `restaurant_name`, `borough`, `zip`, and `seating_interest_sidewalk`. The dataset also indicates whether the restaurant is approved for sidewalk or roadway seating and if they qualify to serve alcohol. Dimensions of sidewalk and roadway seating areas are provided where applicable. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze the distribution of outdoor dining options across the city, understand the demand for different types of seating, and assess the impact of the Open Restaurants program. The data also includes community board and council district information for further analysis.

title: NYC Historical Vital Records: Index to Digitized Marriage Certificates
ufd: This dataset provides an index to digitized historical marriage certificates from 1866-1937 for all five NYC boroughs. It includes information such as the first and last names of the individuals getting married, along with a soundex code for phonetic matching. The data also specifies the county (primarily Kings county in this sample), the certificate number, and the year, month, and day of the marriage. Researchers, genealogists, and historians can use this dataset to locate and access historical marriage records. The 'number' column likely refers to a unique identifier for each marriage certificate. This dataset can be used to study marriage trends, family history, and demographic changes in New York City.

title: 2019 Yellow Taxi Trip Data
ufd: This dataset contains trip records from yellow taxis, capturing details of individual taxi trips. Each row represents a single trip, including pick-up and drop-off dates/times, locations, and trip distances. Key columns include `tpep_pickup_datetime` and `tpep_dropoff_datetime` for timestamps, `pulocationid` and `dolocationid` for location identifiers, and `trip_distance` for the length of the trip. The dataset also provides information on fares, payment types, and passenger counts. Researchers and analysts can use this data to study taxi ridership patterns, analyze fare structures, or investigate the impact of location on trip characteristics. The `vendorid` column identifies the Technology Service Providers (TSPs) that submitted the trip record. Additionally, the `store_and_fwd_flag` indicates if the trip record was temporarily stored in the vehicle before being sent to the vendor.

title: NYCHA Development Data Book
ufd: This dataset provides detailed information on New York City Housing Authority (NYCHA) developments as of January 1, 2025. It includes a variety of data points, such as development names and identification numbers, program types (e.g., FEDERAL, MIXED FINANCE), construction methods (CONVENTIONAL, TURNKEY), and building types (NEW CONST, REHAB). Key columns include the number of apartments, rental rooms, population, and building characteristics like the number of stories and total area. Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to analyze housing development trends, assess the distribution of affordable housing resources, and understand the physical characteristics of NYCHA properties. The data also contains financial information, such as development costs and average monthly gross rent, which can be used for economic analysis. Additionally, political district information is included, allowing for analysis of housing data within specific geographic boundaries. The dataset also includes information on the number of residential and non-residential buildings, stairhalls, and building coverage.
sfd:

title: SBS Certified Business List
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive list of certified businesses in New York City, particularly those participating in the Minority and Women-owned Business Enterprise (M/WBE) Program. It includes detailed information about each business, such as their formal name (`vendor_formal_name`), "doing business as" name (`vendor_dba`), a description of their services (`business_description`), and contact information (`telephone`, `website`). Key columns also specify the type of certification the business holds (`certification`), its ethnicity (`ethnicity`), and location details including address, city, state, and zip code. Furthermore, the dataset offers insights into the businesses' operations through NAICS codes, client job experience, and contract values. Researchers, policymakers, and businesses can use this dataset to identify potential partners, analyze the distribution of certified businesses across different sectors and locations, and understand the economic impact of M/WBE programs. The inclusion of location data (`city`, `state`, `zip`) enables spatial analysis, while certification and ethnicity data support diversity and inclusion studies.
sfd:

title: SweepNYC Street Cleaning
ufd: This dataset provides information on street cleaning activities in New York City, specifically tracking when street segments were last visited by mechanical brooms. It is connected to the SweepNYC tool, which allows residents to monitor the progress of street sweepers. The dataset includes the `physical_id`, a unique identifier for each street segment, and the `date_visited`, indicating the last time a mechanical broom cleaned that segment. The `cscl_version` column specifies the version of the NYC Street Centerline software used. This data can be used to analyze street cleaning frequency, identify areas that may require more attention, and assess the overall effectiveness of the city's street cleaning program. Researchers, city planners, and residents can leverage this information to gain insights into street sanitation efforts. The dataset contains 100 rows of data.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**

It includes the unique identifier for each street segment (`physical_id`), the date of the last cleaning (`date_visited`), and the version of the NYC Street Centerline software used (`cscl_version`). This information is linked to the SweepNYC tool, enabling residents to track street sweeper progress.

title: Population and Languages of the Limited English Proficient (LEP) Speakers by Community District
ufd: This dataset provides insights into the languages spoken by residents of New York City who have limited English proficiency (LEP). It focuses on the estimated number of LEP individuals and a subset of citizens of voting age (CVALEP) within each community district. Key columns include the language spoken, the estimated LEP population, and the estimated CVALEP population. While this sample focuses on the "Battery Park City, Tribeca" area of Manhattan, the full dataset covers all 59 community districts in NYC. The data, derived from the Census Bureau's American Community Survey (ACS) for the 2015-2019 period, can be used to understand the linguistic diversity within different communities. This information can help inform policies and resource allocation for language assistance programs and voter outreach initiatives. Researchers, policymakers, and community organizations can leverage this data to better serve the needs of LEP residents in New York City.
sfd:

title: FDNY Firehouse Listing
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive listing of FDNY firehouse locations and companies across New York City. Each record details the firehouse name and address, along with its location specified by borough, postcode, latitude, and longitude. The dataset also includes administrative information, such as community board and community council districts, as well as census tract and neighborhood tabulation area (NTA). Key columns for identifying a firehouse's location are postcode, borough, and NTA. Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to analyze the distribution of firehouses, assess emergency response coverage, or integrate firehouse locations with other community resources. The dataset includes building identification numbers (BIN and BBL) for linking to property information.
sfd:

title: 911 End-to-End Data
ufd: This dataset provides insights into the efficiency of New York City's 911 response system. It contains data on incident response times for the NYPD, FDNY, and EMS, broken down by incident type and date. Key columns include the date of the incident, the responding agency (NYPD, FDNY, or EMS), the final incident type, and various timestamps measuring the duration of different stages of the response, such as call pickup, dispatch, and arrival. The dataset also includes median and average response times for different agencies. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze response time trends, identify areas for improvement in the 911 system, and compare the performance of different agencies. The number of incidents calculated for each incident type is also provided.
sfd:

title: New York City Community Health Survey
ufd: This dataset contains information from the New York City Community Health Survey (CHS), an annual telephone survey conducted by the DOHMH. It provides data on the health of New Yorkers, including estimates on chronic diseases and behavioral risk factors. The dataset includes the year of the survey, prevalence estimates, and lower and upper 95% confidence intervals for a range of health-related questions (q_1 to q_10). Each 'q' column likely represents responses or measurements related to specific health indicators. Researchers and public health professionals can use this data to analyze trends in health outcomes, identify areas of concern, and inform public health interventions in New York City. The data spans from 2010 to 2020, allowing for longitudinal analysis.
sfd:

title: NYC Citywide Rolling Calendar Sales
ufd: This dataset contains information about real estate sales in New York City, specifically focusing on properties in areas like Alphabet City. Each row represents a sale and includes details about the property's location, building class, tax class, and sale price. Key columns include 'borough', 'neighborhood', 'building_class_category', 'tax_class_at_present', 'sale_price', and 'sale_date'. The dataset also provides information on the number of residential and commercial units, as well as building square footage and year built. Researchers and real estate professionals can use this dataset to analyze sales trends, property values, and investment opportunities within specific neighborhoods. The data can also be used to understand the distribution of different building types and tax classes across the city. Note that some columns, such as 'residential_units', 'commercial_units', 'land_square_feet' and 'apartment_number', have a high percentage of missing values.
sfd:

title: Street Sign Work Orders
ufd: This dataset contains information about street sign work orders in New York City, managed by the Department of Transportation. It includes both current and historical records of regulatory, warning, guide, and parking signs. Key columns include the `order_number`, `record_type` (historical or current), `borough` where the sign is located, the `on_street` and `from_street` to specify the location, and the `order_completed_on_date`. The `sign_code` and `sign_description` provide details about the type of sign. Other columns like `sign_size`, `distance_from_intersection`, and coordinates (`sign_x_coord`, `sign_y_coord`) offer more specific information about the sign's characteristics and placement. Researchers, city planners, or residents could use this data to analyze sign distribution across boroughs, track the types of signs being installed or maintained, or investigate the timeline of sign-related work orders. The data could also be used to assess the proximity of signs to intersections and identify potential areas for improvement in signage.
sfd:

title: NYPD Personnel Demographics
ufd: This dataset provides demographic information for NYPD members of service. It includes details such as gender, race, and sex of the personnel. The dataset also specifies the type of member of service (MOS), their rank, and application date. The 'yearsonjob' column indicates the number of years the person has been employed, and 'yearsonjob_bins' provides a binned version of this data. This dataset could be used to analyze the demographic composition of the NYPD, identify trends in hiring, or explore the distribution of years of service among different groups. However, the current dataset only contains data for male, white, uniform police officers with 0 years on the job, all with the same application date, which limits its analytical value.
sfd:

title: NYC Historical Vital Records: Index to Digitized Death Certificates
ufd: This dataset provides an index to digitized historical death certificates from New York City between 1862 and 1948. It includes records from all five boroughs. Each entry contains the first name, last name, and a Soundex code to aid in searching for similar-sounding names. The county (borough) where the death was recorded is also included. The dataset also specifies the age of the deceased at the time of death, along with the year, month, and day the death certificate was issued. Researchers and genealogists can use this dataset to locate specific death certificates and gather information about individuals who died in New York City during this period. The Soundex code can be particularly helpful when dealing with variations in spelling.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

It provides key information like first name, last name, Soundex code, county (borough), age at death, and the date the death certificate was issued. This allows users to efficiently locate specific death certificates and extract relevant details about individuals who died in NYC during this period.

title: Street Resurfacing Schedule
ufd: This dataset provides a weekly schedule of street resurfacing work performed by the NYC DOT. It includes information on the location of the work, specifying the borough, street names (onstreet, fromstreet, and tostreet), and community board. The dataset also details the type of work being done (paving or milling), the crew type (in-house), and the shift (day or night). The date column indicates when the work is scheduled. Note that schedules are subject to change. You can use this dataset to identify planned street work in your area, understand the types of projects being undertaken, and anticipate potential traffic disruptions.

title: New York City Tax Revenue Actuals
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed look at New York City's tax revenue actuals from fiscal year 2001 onwards, updated annually. It breaks down revenue by source, such as Cigarette Tax, Real Property Tax, and Commercial Rent Tax. The `fisc_yr` column indicates the fiscal year for the reported revenue, while the `tx_nm` column specifies the type of tax. The `amt` column represents the actual revenue collected for that tax type in millions of dollars. The `pub_dt` column indicates the date the data was published. This dataset is valuable for anyone interested in analyzing trends in NYC's tax revenue, understanding the contribution of different tax sources, or comparing revenue across fiscal years. It can be used to match charts and tables in the Mayor's Message publication related to tax revenue.
sfd:

title: Expense Budget
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed view of the expense budget for a city government, specifically focusing on agency-level spending. It breaks down the budget by unit of appropriation, offering insights into how funds are allocated across different departments and programs. Key columns include `agency_name` (e.g., POLICE DEPARTMENT), `unit_appropriation_name` (e.g., ADMINISTRATION-OTPS), `budget_code_name` (e.g., Headquarters Custodial Section), and `object_code_name` (e.g., CONTRACTUAL SERVICES GENERAL), which together define where the money is going. The dataset also includes budget amounts for adopted, financial plan, and modified budget conditions, allowing for comparisons and analysis of budget changes over time. Researchers, city planners, and budget analysts can use this data to understand spending patterns, track budget modifications, and identify areas for potential savings or investment. The data is updated three times a year, providing a current snapshot of the city's financial planning.

title: Heat Vulnerability Index Rankings
ufd: This dataset provides a Heat Vulnerability Index (HVI) for neighborhoods, indicating the risk of residents dying during extreme heat events. The HVI ranges from 1 (lowest risk) to 5 (highest risk), based on factors like surface temperature, green space, air conditioning access, and the percentage of low-income or Black residents. The dataset includes a column, `zcta20`, representing the ZIP Code Tabulation Area (ZCTA), and `hvi`, the corresponding Heat Vulnerability Index score. This data can be used to identify and prioritize resources for neighborhoods most vulnerable to heat-related deaths. Researchers, policymakers, and community organizations can use this information to develop targeted interventions, such as cooling centers or public health campaigns. Understanding the HVI distribution across different ZCTAs allows for a data-driven approach to mitigating the impacts of extreme heat. The index considers historical and systemic inequities that contribute to heat vulnerability.
sfd:

This data allows for the identification of areas most vulnerable to extreme heat.

title: Waiting List for General Vendor Licenses
ufd: This dataset contains information on the waiting list for General Vendor licenses in New York City. It includes details on each applicant, such as their name, address (city, state, and postcode), and their assigned priority number on the waiting list. The dataset also tracks the application order number and a unique identifier for each waiting list application. The `waiting_list_status` column indicates the current status of the application, such as "Awaiting Waitlist Selection" or "Applied for License." The `selection_date` column shows when an applicant was selected from the waiting list, and the `license_application_id` links to the actual license application. This data could be used to analyze the demographics of vendor license applicants, track the progress of applications through the waiting list, or understand the geographic distribution of vendors in the city. Researchers and city planners might use this data to assess the demand for vendor licenses and evaluate the effectiveness of the licensing process.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides details on the waiting list for General Vendor licenses in New York City. It includes applicant information like name, address, priority number, and application order. Key fields include waiting list status, selection date, and a link to the license application ID, offering a comprehensive view of the vendor licensing process.

- License Application ID: Permit number, tracking number, reference ID

title: Vehicle Auction List
ufd: This dataset provides a list of vehicles scheduled for auction by the city government. It includes key details about each vehicle, such as the year it was manufactured, the make (e.g., FORD, MACK), and the specific model. Each vehicle is also identified by its unique Vehicle Identification Number (VIN). The `auction_close_date` indicates when the auction for each vehicle is scheduled to end. This information could be valuable for prospective buyers looking for specific types of vehicles, or for city officials tracking the auction process and the types of assets being sold. The dataset contains 100 rows of vehicle information. Note that the auction close dates are primarily concentrated on three dates in late October and early November 2025.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset details vehicles scheduled for auction by a city government. It includes vehicle characteristics like year, make, model, and VIN. The dataset also specifies the `auction_close_date` for each vehicle, indicating when bidding will end.

title: Medallion Taxi Initial Inspection Schedule
ufd: This dataset provides a schedule of initial inspections for Medallion Taxicabs. It includes information on the first inspection month, as well as the scheduled date and time for the third inspection. The medallion number uniquely identifies each taxi. Fleet agent codes and agent names are also included, potentially linking inspections to specific fleet management companies. The dataset is updated quarterly and can be used to understand the inspection schedule and plan for taxi maintenance. Note that the second inspection schedule date and time columns have a high percentage of missing values. The last updated date and time indicates when the data was last modified.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset details the initial and third inspection schedules for Medallion Taxicabs, identified by their medallion number. It includes the month of the first inspection, scheduled date and time for the third inspection, fleet agent codes, and agent names. title: DOHMH Dog Bite Data
ufd: This dataset contains information on reported dog bites in Brooklyn, New York City. The data includes the date of the bite, the species (limited to dogs in this dataset), breed, gender, and spay/neuter status of the dog. It also provides the borough (Brooklyn) and zipcode where the bite occurred, along with the reported age of the dog. This information is collected by the NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene to monitor animal bites and prevent the spread of rabies. Researchers and public health officials can use this data to analyze trends in dog bites, identify high-risk areas, and develop targeted prevention strategies. Please note that information on breed, age, gender and spayed/neutered status have not been verified by DOHMH.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details reported dog bites in Brooklyn, New York City. It includes information such as the date and location (zipcode) of the bite, as well as details about the dog involved, including breed, gender, spay/neuter status, and age. title: DOB NOW: Safety – Facades Compliance Filings
ufd: This dataset contains information on facade compliance filings submitted through DOB NOW for properties in New York City. Each row represents a single filing, identified by a unique TR6 number and control number. Key details include the filing type (e.g., Initial, Amended), the cycle it pertains to, and the building's address (house number, street name, borough, block, and lot). The dataset also provides the current and filing status of the property, along with associated late filing, failure to file, and failure to collect amounts. Additional information includes the submission date, names of involved parties (QEWI name, owner name), and relevant dates for field inspections and signatures. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze compliance rates, identify areas with high non-compliance, and track the progress of facade inspections and repairs across the city. The comments field, though sparsely populated, may offer valuable insights into specific cases and circumstances.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details facade compliance filings submitted via DOB NOW for New York City properties. title: 2012 SAT Results
ufd: This dataset contains school-level SAT results for New York City graduating seniors in 2012. It includes the number of SAT test takers and the average scores for critical reading, math, and writing sections. Each row represents a specific school, identified by its DBN (District Borough Number) and school name. Note that the data contains 100 rows, but some score values are flagged as "s" which likely indicates suppressed data. This dataset could be used to analyze SAT performance across different schools, identify high-performing schools, or investigate factors that may influence SAT scores. Researchers and educators might find this data useful for evaluating educational outcomes and informing school improvement initiatives.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides school-level SAT results for New York City graduating seniors in 2012. It includes the number of test takers and average scores for critical reading, math, and writing. title: Local Law 79/2022 and 136/2024 - Temporary Housing Assistance Usage
ufd: This dataset provides a monthly overview of temporary housing assistance usage in New York City, as mandated by Local Laws 79/2022 and 136/2024. It includes data on individuals and families utilizing city-administered facilities, exits from these facilities, and waitlist information. Key columns include 'agency' (the reporting city agency), 'category' (the type of data, such as average daily census or exits), and 'facility_or_program_type' (the specific type of housing facility or program). The dataset also provides demographic breakdowns, including the number of families with children, adult families, single men, and single women. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze trends in temporary housing usage, assess the effectiveness of different programs, and identify areas where additional resources are needed. The 'data_period' column indicates the month for which the data is reported, allowing for longitudinal analysis.
sfd:

title: DOHMH Childcare Center Inspections
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive look at childcare center inspections in New York City. It includes details on center names, addresses (building, street, borough, and zipcode), and contact phone numbers. You can use this data to find information about specific childcare centers, including their legal name and DC ID. The dataset also tracks permit information, such as the permit number and expiration date, along with the current status of the permit. Inspection results, violation details (category, health code subsection, status, and a summary), and inspection dates are included, offering insights into the regulatory compliance of these centers. Furthermore, the dataset provides information on the program type, facility type, childcare type, age range served, and maximum capacity. Researchers, parents, and policymakers can use this dataset to assess childcare quality, identify trends in violations, and make informed decisions about childcare options.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains detailed information on childcare center inspections conducted in New York City. It includes center details like name, address, contact information, permit status, and inspection results. The data also covers violation details, program types, and capacity information, providing a comprehensive view of childcare center operations and regulatory compliance.

title: Active Projects Under Construction
ufd: This dataset provides information on active school construction projects in New York City, including both new capacity projects and capital improvement projects (CIP). Each row represents a specific project, identified by its name, building ID, and address. Key details include the project description, the awarded amount, and the construction type (CIP or CAP). The dataset also includes location information such as borough, city, zip code, latitude, and longitude, as well as community board and council districts. Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to analyze the distribution of school construction projects across the city, track investment in school infrastructure, and assess the types of improvements being made. The dataset also includes neighborhood tabulation area (NTA) and other computed region codes for further geographic analysis. With columns like project description and award amount, one can analyze the costs associated with different types of school projects.
sfd:

This dataset details active school construction projects in New York City, encompassing both new capacity (CAP) and capital improvement (CIP) projects. It includes project-specific information such as name, building ID, address, description, awarded amount, and construction type. Location data, including borough, city, zip code, latitude/longitude, and various district codes, is also provided for each project.

title: Taxi and  For Hire Vehicle (FHV) Relief Stands
ufd: This dataset provides information on the locations of Taxi and For Hire Vehicle (FHV) relief stands throughout New York City. These stands allow drivers to park for up to one hour to take breaks. Each record includes the borough, street address (`on_street`, `from_stree`, `to_street`, `side_of_st`), and a description of the sign posted (`sign_descr`). The `relief_sta` column indicates whether the stand is for Taxis, FHVs, or both. The number of parking spaces available at each stand is listed in the `space_coun` column. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze the distribution of relief stands and assess their adequacy in different areas. Taxi and FHV drivers can use this data to find the nearest relief stand.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the locations and characteristics of Taxi and For-Hire Vehicle (FHV) relief stands across New York City. It includes information such as borough, street address, sign descriptions, and the type of vehicles permitted (Taxi, FHV, or both). The dataset also specifies the number of parking spaces available at each relief stand.

title: Buildings Subject to HPD Jurisdiction
ufd: This dataset contains information on buildings in New York City that fall under the jurisdiction of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD), as mandated by the Housing Maintenance Code. It includes details on buildings that HPD requires registration for, buildings with HPD litigation actions, buildings with complaints, buildings with HPD work orders, and buildings in the AEP program. Key columns include `buildingid` for unique identification, `boro` indicating the borough, `housenumber` and `streetname` for address details, and `zip` for postal code. Additional columns like `block` and `lot` provide further location specificity. The dataset also contains information on the building's `communityboard`, `managementprogram`, and `recordstatus`. Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to analyze housing conditions, track HPD interventions, and understand building characteristics across different neighborhoods. The data can also be used to identify properties that may require additional attention or resources.
sfd:

It encompasses details on building registration, litigation, complaints, work orders, and participation in the AEP program. title: Borough/Community District Report
ufd: This dataset provides a snapshot of social service program participation across New York City. It focuses on the number of individuals and households receiving benefits from SNAP (Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program), Cash Assistance (CA), and Medicaid (MA). The data is broken down by borough and community district, offering a localized view of assistance needs. Key columns include `bc_snap_recipients` and `bc_snap_households`, representing the number of SNAP recipients and households, respectively, and similar columns for CA and MA. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to understand the distribution of social service needs across different communities, track changes in program participation over time (though limited to two months in this sample), and inform resource allocation decisions. The `month` column indicates the reporting period, while `borough` and `community_district` provide geographic context.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

The data is aggregated by borough and community district, providing a granular view of program usage. title: License Applications
ufd: This dataset contains information on license applications submitted to the NYC Department of Consumer and Worker Protection (DCWP). Each row represents a single application, detailing the business name, unique ID, and category of business seeking licensure. Key columns include `application_id`, `business_name`, `business_category` (e.g., Tow Truck Driver, Home Improvement Contractor), `application_type` (New or Renewal), and `status` (Approved, Denied, etc.). The dataset also provides location information such as city, state, and zip code, as well as dates for submission and closure of the application. Researchers and analysts can use this data to understand trends in business licensing, identify popular business categories, and analyze application approval rates across different locations and business types. The `license_number` column can be linked to the DCWP Licenses dataset for further insights.
sfd:

title: LinkNYC Kiosk Locations
ufd: This dataset provides locations and details about LinkNYC kiosks throughout New York City. LinkNYC is a program that aims to provide free Wi-Fi, calling services, and access to social services to the public. The dataset includes information on both the original LinkNYC kiosks and the newer Link5G models. Key columns include `planned_kiosk_type`, indicating the type of kiosk installed, `link_installation_status` showing whether the kiosk is live or removed, and geographic information such as `boro`, `council_district`, `community_board`, `postcode`, `latitude`, and `longitude`. The dataset also contains the installation and activation dates. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze the distribution of LinkNYC kiosks, assess their accessibility, and plan for future deployments.

title: Housing Maintenance Code Complaints and Problems
ufd: This dataset contains records of public complaints regarding New York City Housing Maintenance Code violations. Each row represents a single complaint, identified by a unique `complaint_id` and associated with a specific `building_id`. Key information includes the `received_date` of the complaint, the borough (`borough`), street address (`house_number` and `street_name`), and the nature of the problem (`major_category`, `minor_category`, and `problem_code`). The dataset also provides details on the complaint and problem status, including descriptive text (`status_description`) and dates. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze housing code violation patterns across different boroughs, identify common housing issues, and assess the effectiveness of complaint resolution processes. The inclusion of location data (`latitude`, `longitude`, `post_code`) allows for spatial analysis of housing maintenance issues.
sfd:

title: Open Restaurants Inspections
ufd: This dataset contains inspection records for New York City restaurants participating in the Open Restaurants program. It includes information on restaurant locations, seating choices (sidewalk, roadway, or both), and inspection results. Key columns include `borough` (the borough where the restaurant is located), `restaurantname`, `seatingchoice`, and `isroadwaycompliant`, which indicates whether the restaurant's roadway seating meets regulations. The `inspectedon` column provides the date and time of the inspection. Other location-based columns include `postcode` (zip code), `latitude`, `longitude`, `communityboard`, `councildistrict`, `censustract`, `BIN` (Building Identification Number), and `BBL` (Borough, Block, and Lot). This data could be used to analyze restaurant compliance rates across different boroughs, identify trends in seating choices, or map inspection locations.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides inspection records for New York City restaurants participating in the Open Restaurants program. It details restaurant locations, seating types (sidewalk, roadway, or both), and the results of inspections related to program compliance. Key information includes borough, restaurant name, seating choice, roadway compliance status, and inspection date.

- Seating Choice: Sidewalk Seating, Roadway Seating, Outdoor Seating
- Compliance: Regulation Adherence, Inspection Results, Violation Status
- Borough: NYC Borough, Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, Bronx, Staten Island
- Inspection Date: Inspected On, Date of Inspection

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze restaurant compliance rates by borough or seating type.
- Identify trends in seating choices among NYC restaurants.

title: NYC Zoning Tax Lot Database
ufd: This dataset provides up-to-date zoning information for tax lots in New York City. Updated monthly, it includes zoning designations and zoning maps associated with specific tax blocks and lots. Key columns include `borough_code`, `tax_block`, `tax_lot`, and `bbl` (Borough, Block, Lot), which together uniquely identify a property. The `zoning_district_1` column specifies the primary zoning district for a property, while `special_district_1` indicates any special zoning districts that apply. The `zoning_map_number` column refers to the specific zoning map that applies to the property. This dataset can be used to understand the zoning regulations in effect for a particular property, analyze zoning patterns across the city, or identify areas subject to special zoning regulations. Researchers, developers, and city planners can leverage this data for various analyses and decision-making processes related to land use and development.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

It includes zoning designations, zoning maps, and property identifiers like borough code, tax block, and tax lot. title: Individual Census by Borough, Community District, and Facility Type
ufd: This dataset provides a census of individuals in various shelter types across New York City, broken down by borough and community district. The data includes counts for adult shelters, family shelters with children, and adult family shelters, further categorized by standard shelters and commercial hotel settings. Key columns include `report_date` indicating the reporting period, `borough` and `community_districts` specifying the location, and columns like `adult_shelter` and `family_with_chidren_shelter` representing the number of individuals in each shelter type. The `census_type` column specifies that the data is for individuals. Researchers and policymakers can use this dataset to analyze shelter utilization patterns, identify areas with high demand for specific shelter types, and track changes in shelter populations over time. The data spans across Brooklyn, Manhattan, Bronx, Queens, and Staten Island. Note that some columns, such as `adult_family_comm_hotel`, have a high percentage of missing values.
sfd:

It provides counts for various shelter types, including adult shelters, family shelters with children, and adult family shelters, further distinguished by standard shelters and commercial hotels. title: Greenbook
ufd: This dataset provides a directory of New York City government agencies, offices, boards, and commissions. It includes contact information for various levels of New York City government, including County and the unified Courts system. Key columns include `agency_name`, `first_name`, `last_name`, `office_title`, `address`, `city`, `state`, `zip_code`, `agency_primary_phone`, and `agency_website`. You can use this dataset to find contact information for government employees, identify the correct agency for a specific issue, or understand the organizational structure of New York City government. The dataset also includes agency acronyms and division names to further refine your search. Information such as phone numbers and websites are included to facilitate contact with the relevant agencies and personnel. The `section` column categorizes listings as City, Courts, or County.

title: DOB NOW: Certificate of Occupancy
ufd: This dataset contains information on Certificates of Occupancy (CO) issued through the NYC Department of Buildings' DOB NOW module, starting in March 2021. A CO indicates the legal use and permitted occupancy type of a building. The data includes details such as the job filing name, job type (e.g., new building, alteration), building identification number (BIN), street address, and the CO's status, sequence number, filing type, and issuance date. Location information is provided through borough, zip code, community district, city council district, census tract, and neighborhood name (NTAname), as well as latitude/longitude coordinates. Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to analyze building development trends, track CO issuance timelines, and assess compliance with building regulations across different geographic areas of New York City. The dataset can also be used to understand the types of construction projects happening in specific neighborhoods.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

It includes information on building projects, such as job type, address, and CO status, along with geographic details like borough, zip code, and coordinates. title: DOF Property Abatement Detail
ufd: This dataset provides details on property tax abatements administered by the Department of Finance. It includes information on abatements at the parcel, condominium, and cooperative levels. Key columns include `parid` (parcel identifier), `taxyr` (tax year), `caseno` (case number), `tccode` (tax class code), and `leasearea` (lease area). Dates like `yrbegdt` and `yrenddt` indicate the start and end dates of the abatement. The `bldgsqft` column shows the building square footage. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze trends in property tax abatements, understand their impact on city revenue, and evaluate the effectiveness of different abatement programs. The dataset also includes historical abatement data, with the maximum `EXTRACTDT` value indicating the current abatement data.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details property tax abatements managed by the Department of Finance, covering parcel, condominium, and cooperative levels. It includes key identifiers like parcel ID (`parid`), tax year (`taxyr`), and case number (`caseno`), along with abatement details such as lease area (`leasearea`) and building square footage (`bldgsqft`). The data allows for analysis of abatement trends and their impact on city revenue.

title: ACRIS - Real Property References
ufd: This dataset contains cross-references for real property documents recorded in the Automated City Register Information System (ACRIS). It allows users to trace the relationships between different documents related to a single property. Each record includes a `document_id` and a `record_type`, along with several fields that provide reference information. Key reference fields include `reference_by_crfn_` (case reference number), `reference_by_reel_year`, `reference_by_reel_borough`, `reference_by_reel_nbr` (reel number), and `reference_by_reel_page`. The `good_through_date` indicates the expiration date of the reference. Researchers and property analysts can use this data to investigate property ownership history, identify related legal documents, and understand the context of real estate transactions in the city. Note that `reference_by_doc_id` has many missing values.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

title: School Quality Reports Data
ufd: This dataset provides insights into school performance metrics for New York City schools. It includes data from the 2020 school year with reports generated in 2021. Key columns include `school_name`, `school_type` (Elementary or K-8), `metric_display_name` (e.g., "Average Student Attendance"), `number_of_students`, and `metric_value`. The `dbn` column provides a unique identifier for each school. The data focuses on a variety of attendance-related metrics, including in-person and remote attendance, as well as chronic absenteeism, broken down by demographic groups. Users can analyze this data to understand school performance trends, compare schools, and identify areas for improvement. This dataset is a valuable resource for educators, policymakers, and researchers interested in understanding and improving school quality.
sfd:

title: New York City Bike Routes
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive view of New York City's bike routes, both current and historical, managed by the NYC DOT. It includes detailed information about the type of bicycle facility, its location, and relevant street details represented as line segments. Key columns include `the_geom` which contains the geographic coordinates of the bike route segments, `street`, `fromstreet`, and `tostreet` which specify the street names and segment endpoints, and `boro` indicating the borough. The `bikeid` column provides a unique identifier for each bike route segment, while `status` indicates whether the route is currently active or retired. Researchers, urban planners, and cyclists can use this dataset to analyze the city's bicycle infrastructure, plan routes, and understand the evolution of bike facilities over time. The dataset also includes information on installation and retirement dates (`instdate` and `ret_date`), facility classifications (`facilitycl`), and lane counts (`lanecount`).
sfd:

title: NYC Greenhouse Gas Emissions Inventory
ufd: This dataset provides an inventory of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in New York City, tracking the city's progress in reducing them. It includes data on various emission sources, categorized by inventory type (GPC, CLCPA Addition, Total), sector (e.g., Transportation, Stationary Energy, Waste), and specific categories like residential, commercial, or transportation types. The dataset details the full and labeled source of emissions, along with the units of measurement. Key numerical columns include the amount of energy consumed, total carbon dioxide equivalent emissions (TCO2e) using both 100-year and 20-year global warming potential (GWP) metrics, and the energy consumption in MMBTU (million British thermal units). The dataset covers emissions from 2005 to 2023, with columns showing the percentage change in consumption, emissions, and source energy between 2005 and 2022. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze emission trends, identify key areas for reduction efforts, and assess the effectiveness of implemented strategies.
sfd:

title: Open Streets Locations
ufd: This dataset provides information on New York City's Open Streets program, which transforms streets into public spaces. Each row represents a specific Open Street location. Key details include the organization responsible for the street ("orgname"), the street name ("appronstre"), the borough ("boroughname"), and the start and end streets of the open street segment ("apprfromst" and "apprtostre"). The dataset also specifies the days of the week the street is open ("apprdayswe"), the approval status ("reviewstat"), and the start and end dates ("apprstartd" and "apprenddat"). The dataset includes opening and closing times for each day of the week. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze the program's reach, understand the distribution of open streets across boroughs, and assess the operational characteristics of these public spaces.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

It includes information on the organization managing each open street, its location details (street name, borough, start and end streets), and operational specifics like days and times of operation. The dataset also tracks approval status and the start and end dates of the program at each location.

title: Affordable Housing Production by Project
ufd: This dataset provides details on affordable housing projects in New York City, tracked by the Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD). It includes projects that began after January 1, 2014, and contribute to the Housing New York or Housing Our Neighbors plans. Key information includes the project's name, ID, the program group it falls under (e.g., Multifamily Finance Program), and its start and completion dates. The dataset also specifies the number of units dedicated to different income levels, such as extremely low, very low, low, moderate, and middle-income residents. Additional details cover the extended affordability status, prevailing wage status, and planned tax benefits associated with each project. Researchers, policymakers, and housing advocates can use this data to analyze affordable housing production trends, assess the impact of various housing programs, and understand the distribution of affordable units across different income brackets. The data allows for examining the types of tax benefits utilized and the prevalence of prevailing wages in affordable housing developments.
sfd:

title: Order to Repair/Vacate Orders
ufd: This dataset contains information on Order to Repair/Vacate Orders issued for properties in New York City. Each row represents a specific vacate order, identified by a unique building ID and registration ID. Key details include the borough (`boro_short_name`), house number, and street name where the order was issued. The dataset also specifies the `primary_vacate_reason` (e.g., Fire Damage, Illegal Occupancy) and the `vacate_type` (Partial or Entire Building). You can find the effective date of the vacate order (`vacate_effective_date`) and, if applicable, the date when the order was rescinded (`actual_rescind_date`). Additional geographic information is provided, such as the postal code (`postoce`), latitude, longitude, community board, council district, and neighborhood tabulation area (NTA). This data could be used to analyze trends in vacate orders, identify areas with high rates of housing violations, or assess the impact of vacate orders on communities. The number of vacated units is also recorded (`number_of_vacated_units`).
sfd:

The dataset also includes dates related to the order's effectiveness and rescission, as well as geographic identifiers like community board and council district.

title: Civilian Complaint Review Board: Police Officers
ufd: This dataset provides a list of NYPD officers and the number of complaints they have received since 2000, as reported to the Civilian Complaint Review Board (CCRB) by the NYPD. Key columns include officer first and last names, race, gender, current rank and its abbreviation, and current command. The dataset also tracks the officer's active status, the date of their last reported activity, shield number, total complaints, and total substantiated complaints. Researchers and the public can use this data to analyze complaint patterns against officers, examine demographic trends within the police force, and assess the effectiveness of accountability measures. The `as_of_date` column indicates the date the officer data was reported. This dataset is part of a larger collection of public police misconduct records maintained by the CCRB.

title: 311 Service Level Agreements
ufd: This dataset outlines the City of New York's service level agreements (SLAs) for 311 service requests, detailing the city's commitment to addressing various issues. It includes 100 rows of data, with each row representing a specific type of service request and its corresponding SLA. The key columns include "agency," indicating the responsible city agency (e.g., Department of Buildings, Department of Sanitation), and "problem," specifying the nature of the service request (e.g., Advertising Sign, Snow or Ice). The "sla_days" column shows the expected timeframe for the agency to respond to the request. Additional columns, "problem_details" and "additional_details," provide further context and specifics about the issue. This dataset is useful for understanding the city's responsiveness to different types of 311 requests, identifying potential bottlenecks in service delivery, and holding city agencies accountable for meeting their service commitments. The data could be used by city planners, government watchdogs, and residents interested in tracking the performance of city services.
sfd:

title: TLC Industry Indicators
ufd: This dataset provides monthly insights into the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission (TLC) industry. It includes key metrics like average daily trips, fare collection, and the number of active vehicles and drivers. The data is broken down by license class, such as yellow taxis, green taxis, and for-hire vehicles (FHV). Key columns include `month_year` for the time period, `license_class` to differentiate vehicle types, `trips_per_day` for ridership volume, and `farebox_per_day` to track revenue. Researchers and analysts can use this dataset to understand trends in the TLC industry, analyze the impact of different vehicle types, and monitor economic performance. The dataset also includes information on average durations and payment methods.
sfd:

The data allows for analysis of trends and performance within the NYC for-hire transportation sector.

title: 2020-2021 Demographic Snapshot School
ufd: This dataset provides a demographic snapshot of schools, including enrollment and demographic information, collected across multiple years. Each row represents a specific school and year, identified by the 'dbn' and 'school_name' columns. The dataset includes the 'year' of the snapshot, the 'total_enrollment', and enrollment counts for each grade from pre-kindergarten ('grade_3k_pk_half_day_full') through grade 12. Additionally, it breaks down the student population by gender ('female', 'male') and race/ethnicity ('asian', 'black', 'hispanic', 'multi_racial', 'native_american', 'white'), both in terms of counts and percentages. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze enrollment trends, demographic shifts, and diversity within the school system over time. The dataset also includes information on students with disabilities and English language learners, as well as poverty and economic need indices.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains demographic information and enrollment statistics for schools across multiple years. It includes details on student enrollment by grade, gender, and race/ethnicity, along with data on students with disabilities, English language learners, and economic need. title: Parking Violations Issued - Fiscal Year 2022
ufd: This dataset contains information on parking violations issued in New York City during fiscal year 2022 (July 1, 2021 to June 30, 2022). Each row represents a single parking ticket. Key details include the `summons_number`, `plate_id`, `registration_state`, `issue_date`, and `violation_code`. The dataset also provides location information using `street_code1`, `street_code2`, and `street_code3`, as well as the `violation_precinct`. You can use this data to analyze parking violation patterns across the city, identify common violations, or examine the relationship between vehicle characteristics and parking tickets. Please note that the dataset reflects the status of violations at the time of issuance and may not reflect current status. For current violation status, refer to the Open Parking & Camera Violations dataset.
sfd:

title: Participatory Budgeting Projects
ufd: This dataset contains information on Participatory Budgeting projects in New York City, a process where community members decide how to spend part of the public budget. Each row represents a specific project proposal. Key columns include the `vote_year`, `council_district` where the project was proposed, the `category` of the project (e.g., Parks & Recreation, Schools), a brief `description`, and the `cost` of the project. The `winner` column indicates whether the project was ultimately funded through the participatory budgeting process. Researchers and city planners could use this dataset to analyze trends in community needs and priorities across different council districts. The data also includes location information such as `address`, `latitude`, and `longitude` for some projects.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

It includes information on project proposals, their costs, locations, categories, and whether they were ultimately funded.
